reviewText: I can't praise this game enough. I love all forms of rock and soft metal music. From a very early age I always wanted to play guitar but will openly admit that my skills don't match my enthusiasm. Many years ago I tried electric guitar and wasn't very good. I eventually gave up through lack of improvement and and injury where I lost my left middle finger tip. It wasn't until just over a year ago when I was fancying the idea of trying guitar again. Because of my finger I thought about trying bass and out of the blue my girlfriend bought me a bass starter set for my Christmas present. I was immediately hooked but again my enthusiasm exceeded my skills, then I came across Rocksmith 2014. For me it has been a revelation and although I accept the purist musicians might not think it's great for people like myself that have a love for music but lack the skill it is a must to have. I don't have a very good memory and can't really play son's without out the help of Rocksmith 2014 but the big incentive is that I can now play music to which I consider a pretty good standard. I am now the guy that has all the gear and no idea lol. I bought myself a Schecter stiletto custom 4 bass with an Orange bass amp and various pedals and use Rocksmith to compliment them. While i'm realistic and know that i'm no Duff McKegan I couldn't have achieved what I have without rocksmith and in the end of the day I have fun and enjoy it which is what it's all about. For other people like myself I couldn't recommend Rocksmith 2014 enough. I would like to add that what you get for the price is an understatement. I would dread to think how much money I would have spent on lessons to get to the stage i'm at. While I accept with tuition I might be at a better standard for the cost difference involved it doesn't compare. Also initially I played this on my PS3 but moved to using my PC as I love being able to have such a massive library of custom songs available to me through customforge.com\n\nI can honestly say that I only have found two drawbacks but this is not due to the game itself as the things I am doing are outwith what the game was originally designed for. I'm a bit of a gadget geek and I use Rocksmith via my amp and tv for sound by using a switch blade+ spliter which can sometimes cause issues with the real tone cable and also the game very rarely crashes after prolonged use using custom songs. But as I say these aren't official features of the game so it's unfair to mark it down on these cases.

reviewText:
After a lifelong career as an air guitarist, and several instances of complete failure trying to teach myself guitar, I decided to try Rocksmith.  A couple of years later I'm actually a passable guitar player.

What the game will not do:
It won't make you Joe Satriani, Steve Vai, Guthrie Govan, or guitar hero x.
It won't hold your hand or answer every minor question you have when you first start playing.
It won't teach you all the theory behind the songs you're playing.

What the game will do:
It will teach you enough theory to get by (via some pretty generic lessons and mini games).
It will introduce you to improvisation (session mode).
It will probably introduce you to some pretty cool music you haven't heard before.
Possibly trigger a mid-life crisis.
Probably turn you into a guitar gear junky.

But most importantly it will get you past those first HUGE humps to learning guitar - building callouses, finger dexterity, and getting in some effective practice.  The biggest roadblock for me on my previous attempts to learn was wondering WTF to play when I did sit down to practice.  This game helped me personally with that a lot since you can just flip on a great song and play along without turning the pages in some book or trying to decipher a tab.  The dynamic difficulty has some quirks no doubt, but in the end you can always manually adjust what level you want the song at (for those wondering how to do this, just put the whole song in riff repeater).  So even beginners can fire up Satch Boogie and just put it on the lowest difficulty and play along (admittedly even on lowest difficulty this one could be tough for beginners).

In the end, I would call this an extremely effective introduction for brand new guitar players, and a very good practice tool for beginners and intermediate players.  If you can't get into playing using this software, then playing guitar may not be for you.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
After reaching all 47 achievements, I guess its time for a review.  This game is the most awesome learning experience for a musical instrument I've ever encountered in any media.  I've tried learning guitar a few times in the past but it was boring and painful making it hard to stick with it.  This game isn't perfect but it gets so much right, you just want to keep coming back for more.  I hope this game has a very long life.

One of the achievements was bass only so I decided to get the Electro-Harmonix PitchFork pedal so I could switch between playing all 3 paths (lead, rhythm, bass) at the press of a button.  That was a great addition to my setup and opened up all the bass items which are a lot of fun too.  I'm playing with a basic starter guitar: Epiphone Special II.

Pros: The most motivating features for me were the achievements and the methods for grading your progress.  Each song has 5 ways of scoring your progress (Learn A Song percentage, 4 levels of Score Attack) that makes me want to ace them all.  Learn A Song supports a breadth-first progression through a song (gradually adding notes as you get better in each phrase) and Score Attack is an arcade-style depth first progression through a difficulty level (Easy, Medium, Hard, Master).  Master mode hides the notes and was scary at first but its a great motivator for weaning you off the sight-reading and encourages you to listen for cues instead.  Learn A Song also has Riff Repeater which allows you to mark a section and then slow it down and vary the difficulty level -- this is indispensible for getting those hard riffs down.  I also enjoyed working through the Lessons and Guitarcade.  Guitarcade is a collection of about a dozen games and they are an excellent way to get some technique practice in without feeling like you're doing something as boring as scales.  I'd really like to see more of these mini-games as they are much more fun than practice exercises.

Cons: Ubisoft sites really suck at consistency.  Achievements and unlocks are shown on the Ubisoft site, the Rocksmith site, and Steam.  Steam is rock solid but the others are woefully inconsistent and aggravating to use.  500 missions?  Really?  What an annoying achievement!  Guitarcade's Hurtling Hurdles seems much too sensitive and poorly balanced compared to the other games.  Session mode -- the mission system kept pushing this but I found it a dreadful bore since I'm not good enough to improvise anything interesting at this point.

reviewText: I can't praise this game enough. I love all forms of rock and soft metal music. From a very early age I always wanted to play guitar but will openly admit that my skills don't match my enthusiasm. Many years ago I tried electric guitar and wasn't very good. I eventually gave up through lack of improvement and and injury where I lost my left middle finger tip. It wasn't until just over a year ago when I was fancying the idea of trying guitar again. Because of my finger I thought about trying bass and out of the blue my girlfriend bought me a bass starter set for my Christmas present. I was immediately hooked but again my enthusiasm exceeded my skills, then I came across Rocksmith 2014. For me it has been a revelation and although I accept the purist musicians might not think it's great for people like myself that have a love for music but lack the skill it is a must to have. I don't have a very good memory and can't really play son's without out the help of Rocksmith 2014 but the big incentive is that I can now play music to which I consider a pretty good standard. I am now the guy that has all the gear and no idea lol. I bought myself a Schecter stiletto custom 4 bass with an Orange bass amp and various pedals and use Rocksmith to compliment them. While i'm realistic and know that i'm no Duff McKegan I couldn't have achieved what I have without rocksmith and in the end of the day I have fun and enjoy it which is what it's all about. For other people like myself I couldn't recommend Rocksmith 2014 enough. I would like to add that what you get for the price is an understatement. I would dread to think how much money I would have spent on lessons to get to the stage i'm at. While I accept with tuition I might be at a better standard for the cost difference involved it doesn't compare. Also initially I played this on my PS3 but moved to using my PC as I love being able to have such a massive library of custom songs available to me through customforge.com\n\nI can honestly say that I only have found two drawbacks but this is not due to the game itself as the things I am doing are outwith what the game was originally designed for. I'm a bit of a gadget geek and I use Rocksmith via my amp and tv for sound by using a switch blade+ spliter which can sometimes cause issues with the real tone cable and also the game very rarely crashes after prolonged use using custom songs. But as I say these aren't official features of the game so it's unfair to mark it down on these cases.

reviewText:
Rocksmith is a great great if not the best starting point for learning the electric guitar in my opinion. Yes, a personal guitar teacher would be great. It would also be great if you could study music and art at the same time and tour with a band to learn your instrument.
the problem is, not everybody has the time and oportunity to do this kind of stuff, it also involves quite a commitment. This is where rocksmith shines, it gets you playing. Despite all the flaws and the lack of theory it teaches you it gets you started soemwhere you gain not only an understanding on how to play the instrument but also an actual feeling for it.
I'm looking back on playing the guitar for around 1000 hours now thanks to rocksmith, whereas in total the rocksmith hours float around 300ish i think... the other hours i played outside of rocksmith using whatever rocksmith taught me to understand and work on music theory to become an actual musician the way i like it.
Rocksmith will teach the fastest and the most effective on how to improve technically on the guitar. How your fingers move on the fretboard, how to hit your stuff. It won't teach you how to compose a song, or what actual music theory is, but let me tell you this:

it's great WHEN you decide to dip into music theory that your hands are not holding you back anymore because you can translate what you learn so much faster than if you had to learn this from scratch as well. (and THAT is boring as hell).

10/10 for this life changing game.

For anyone who has a guitar laying around, and wants to learn to play. Period.

reviewText:
I've always wanted to play guitar but every time I've tried I got to a point where I'd get bored, reading tabs was confusing for a beginner and I was really having trouble with chords. I've had Rocksmith since February 2014 and at the point of writing this review in July 2015 and after putting in I'd say around 200-300 hours with the xbox 360 version and now the PC version, I've pretty much got to a point where I can play most songs without trouble, some chords I still struggle with and obviously Sweet Child O'Mine can be a tad difficult but I'm definitely pleased with how far I've come in regards to ability.

The learning tools are fun and the skill games in arcade mode are challenging and actually help with remembering notes. The DLC track packs are constantly being rolled out so you're never short of songs to play, not to mention CLDC being made by members of the community (check out Custom's Forge, they have literally thousands of songs to download for free).

As far as the graphics go there's not much to say really, similarly to Rock Band graphics aren't really important, that being said the menu's and in game interfaces are all solid.

Overall, well worth the money, I don't think I'd have ever got to the point where I can actually say yes I can play an instrument.

reviewText:
As a complete beginner with stringed instruments as a whole, I have never before played a song on the guitar, or even held a guitar for more than five minutes without getting bored of it, in just four days, I was already playing full length songs on a beginner level.

Well, until my guitar's high e string snapped while tuning it. I need to get that replaced. :')

This game definitely does teach you guitar. While it may not teach you music theory, it is recommended that you teach yourself on the side so that while Rocksmith teaches you how to master the guitar itself, which it actually does, you can also teach yourself how to play guitar notes on the side so that you can read sheet music.

You can play guitar by ear and skill, sure, but you're only half a musician until you know music theory too.

This game's definitely a great choice for a beginner or even an experienced guitarist.

And yes, it definitely makes practice addicting. I had to stop because my finger was about to bleed and I didn't want to be unable to play the next day. :D

reviewText:
Well, since my wife won't let me get the ol' band back together, this seems to fill the void.
If you have ever considered playing guitar or bass, I think this is an awesome tool & any aspiring guitarist or bass player will lose themselves in this program.  I have a tough time calling it a game because it does so much more. Learn or play along with your favorite tunes & work on the parts that are difficult using the riff repeater to slow down the songs speed without losing pitch. Learning scales, playing in session mode (Jamming) with whatever accompanyment or style you prefer.

If I could ask for one thing Rocksmith 2014 doesnt have, it would be an online multi player mode. That could be potentially alot of fun to hook up with like-minded musicians playing your favorite songs or jamming. But I know, that's probably asking alot. I only wish this was around when I was younger & had the ol' band together.

reviewText:
For a learning tool, this game is a 50/50 situation. It effectively teaches you to play, however since you don't have a teacher next to you, you can often get confused on how to play a part of a song, or potentially get a technique wrong.
This game is very effective when it comes to teaching even then though, so don't be fooled, I couldn't play ANYTHING on my bass before Rocksmith. I could only play.... about... uhm...  two notes on Wrathchild (by iron maiden) and to me, it felt REALLY difficult. But after 20-30 hours on Rocksmith, I could breeze through about 50-80 percent of the song.
150 gaming hours later and I can play just about any song on the setlist and get above at least 80-90 percent.
Being a massive Iron Maiden fan, I was pleased to see Iron Maiden DLC. I currently have 98% on Two Minutes To Midnight and I've reached one hundred percent on Run To The Hills. It feels great acomplishing a song on Rocksmith as it can be very stressful and hard trying to complete a song.

As I've mentioned earlier though, because there is no teacher to help you, it can be very frustrating trying to learn techniques. Especially harder techniques such as Tapping" And "Slap/Pop". And if you simply can't get the technique right
date:
the game will keep making you do it over and over without ANY further tips or advice.
It pulls you by the nose really.

The arcade games are rather dull

reviewText: Before I had ever heard of this game, I had bought a guitar years ago. I always wanted to learn, but never came through to learning how to play a song. I had once in a while picked up the guitar and strummed a few cords, just for the heck of it. Until December 2013 I heard about this new program called Rocksmith 2014, and although I've heard about the Rocksmith 2011 and I heard reviews that the 2011 edition was not accurate guitar teacher, I passed for buying the game. Since I heard about this new 2014 edition, I seemed interested on what all the fuss was about. After reading reviews and watching videos, I finally decided to buy the game. When plugging in my guitar for the first time, I was confused with scheme of the game. When I reversed of to the Learn a Song section, and played a song, I was confused with the notes and did not seem to be getting anywhere to playing the actual song. However, after playing the song for about a half-hour, the notes started to adjust to my ability as I learned the song more and more. I even used the handy riff repeater that can strengthen my skills within the notes of the song by speeding up or slowing down, and/or adjusting the difficulty. The game includes mini games if you ever get bored of Learn a Song and want to practice chords, finger picking, or just strumming the guitar. Don't worry too much about the option as I focus much with Learn a Song and the mini games. And after 8 months and 20 hours of practicing, not including off time practicing, I have learn about 10 songs fully. And the worth the price rather than paying a guitar teacher, in addition to paying the game on your own time.\n-Also supports bass :P\n

reviewText: I saw a guitar teacher in a video on the Internet say that it takes about 3,000 hours of practice for someone to really become decently competent at the guitar. His point was simply that there was no substitute for putting in the time, and no real shortcuts  - though of course good instruction (such as his own) would help.\n\nRS2014 went away from its more gamey" style predecessor to become more of a full-fledged training tool for the guitar. This was a good move. It's easily three times better than the original Rocksmith at meeting this goal. Everything is much
date: MUCH more instructive and convenient. It gives you lots of tools to learn popular (and not-so-popular) songs... really learn them
recommended: to the point where you can completely play them from memory. From the basic "Learn a song" tool to the flexible "Riff Repeater
hoursPlayed: which allows you to practice a section of a song over and over again, to the ability to test yourself at various skill levels in Score Attack - which is a lot like classic Guitar Hero / Rock Band type play. But it also includes dozens of lessons - many with practice tracks. And a number of Guitarcade" technique games to take some of the boredom out of common drills.\n\nYou can simulate a large number of amps

reviewText: Before I had ever heard of this game, I had bought a guitar years ago. I always wanted to learn, but never came through to learning how to play a song. I had once in a while picked up the guitar and strummed a few cords, just for the heck of it. Until December 2013 I heard about this new program called Rocksmith 2014, and although I've heard about the Rocksmith 2011 and I heard reviews that the 2011 edition was not accurate guitar teacher, I passed for buying the game. Since I heard about this new 2014 edition, I seemed interested on what all the fuss was about. After reading reviews and watching videos, I finally decided to buy the game. When plugging in my guitar for the first time, I was confused with scheme of the game. When I reversed of to the Learn a Song section, and played a song, I was confused with the notes and did not seem to be getting anywhere to playing the actual song. However, after playing the song for about a half-hour, the notes started to adjust to my ability as I learned the song more and more. I even used the handy riff repeater that can strengthen my skills within the notes of the song by speeding up or slowing down, and/or adjusting the difficulty. The game includes mini games if you ever get bored of Learn a Song and want to practice chords, finger picking, or just strumming the guitar. Don't worry too much about the option as I focus much with Learn a Song and the mini games. And after 8 months and 20 hours of practicing, not including off time practicing, I have learn about 10 songs fully. And the worth the price rather than paying a guitar teacher, in addition to paying the game on your own time.\n-Also supports bass :P\n

reviewText:
Rocksmith is more than just a game, it is a teaching aid.  It won't turn you into a shredding speedking over night but it will, if you practice and stick with it improve your playing a great deal.  The good thing is you will have fun while learning and it doesn't feel like a chore.

The riff repeater with plenty of options to adjust things like speed, number of attempts before moving on, playing just tricky sections or the entire song is invaluable.  This coupled with the lessons and guitarcade will have you playing full songs in no time.

I would definately recommend this game (Aid) to anyone wanting to learn the guitar.

reviewText:
For a learning tool, this game is a 50/50 situation. It effectively teaches you to play, however since you don't have a teacher next to you, you can often get confused on how to play a part of a song, or potentially get a technique wrong.
This game is very effective when it comes to teaching even then though, so don't be fooled, I couldn't play ANYTHING on my bass before Rocksmith. I could only play.... about... uhm...  two notes on Wrathchild (by iron maiden) and to me, it felt REALLY difficult. But after 20-30 hours on Rocksmith, I could breeze through about 50-80 percent of the song.
150 gaming hours later and I can play just about any song on the setlist and get above at least 80-90 percent.
Being a massive Iron Maiden fan, I was pleased to see Iron Maiden DLC. I currently have 98% on Two Minutes To Midnight and I've reached one hundred percent on Run To The Hills. It feels great acomplishing a song on Rocksmith as it can be very stressful and hard trying to complete a song.

As I've mentioned earlier though, because there is no teacher to help you, it can be very frustrating trying to learn techniques. Especially harder techniques such as Tapping" And "Slap/Pop". And if you simply can't get the technique right
date:
the game will keep making you do it over and over without ANY further tips or advice.
It pulls you by the nose really.

The arcade games are rather dull

reviewText:
Well, since my wife won't let me get the ol' band back together, this seems to fill the void.
If you have ever considered playing guitar or bass, I think this is an awesome tool & any aspiring guitarist or bass player will lose themselves in this program.  I have a tough time calling it a game because it does so much more. Learn or play along with your favorite tunes & work on the parts that are difficult using the riff repeater to slow down the songs speed without losing pitch. Learning scales, playing in session mode (Jamming) with whatever accompanyment or style you prefer.

If I could ask for one thing Rocksmith 2014 doesnt have, it would be an online multi player mode. That could be potentially alot of fun to hook up with like-minded musicians playing your favorite songs or jamming. But I know, that's probably asking alot. I only wish this was around when I was younger & had the ol' band together.

reviewText:
Awesome, awesome game.  I've been playing guitar on and off for about 7 years now.  Rocksmith is amazing for helping to focus my practice efforts.  At times when I want to just sit down for 30 minutes and play, Rocksmith is there waiting for me.

I think it is dangerous to use Rocksmith as a sole teaching device, as some of the more subtle aspects of playing, such as proper position, picking technique, fingering technique, etc, will be overlooked in Rocksmith.

With that caveat, this is an awesome, awesome game.  Guitar Hero - with real guitars!

reviewText:
I will offer a review in two parts.

1) The software itself

2) The steam application that supports it.

The Software Itself.

I was a professional guitarist for a number of years, a guitar teacher for a few more, and have played guitar for somewhere near 30 years.

Rocksmith 2014 is a remarkable tool for entertainment, and most importantly, education. The teaching system is very well realized and the result is a product that gently guides you through the process of learning guitar by teaching you to play songs.

Dynamic and responsive difficulty means the song gets harder as you get better at it, and the recommended lessons that are also in Rocksmith are about 80% relevant.

Since you are using a real guitar, the quality of the experience of actually playing is under your control. So since I use a very carefully set up guitar designed for fast lead, it's a comfortable and pleasant experience even if you get caught up in the features for hours. A cheap squire strat would work just as effectively, but I am sure you would tire more quickly.

The song selection is, in my opinion, diverse to the point of ludicrous but out of the 50 or so songs, you can find a good 15-20 you would probably want to learn.

As an experienced guitarist, I would appreciate the ability to set a certain degree of difficulty for the song so that I don't go through the callibration process of making you play one note instead of 6 chords.

The tone editor is neat and you do get access to a pretty extensive guitar rig" so you can tailor your sound
date: but more often I found myself simply using the tone supplied with the song as generally they were sufficiently well designed to match.\n\nThe session mode is a slightly infuriating combination of unbelievable to unusable. The correct way to fix this would be to allow the guitarist to lead the band
recommended: or have the band start the jam with an intro. While blues works amazingly with a blistering solo lead which sets everything up
hoursPlayed: the other options
voteText: such as funk or metal would be very well served by an intro fill and first few bars to establish the key
helpfulPercent: chord progression and the like.\n\nBlues
votesHelpful: however
votesTotal: is custom made for this (Jazz should be looked into
votesFunny:
but may push the dynamic element too far) and the structure of 12-bar allows you to know where the band will go so you don't need to lead anything other than the actual dynamics of the tune.

Guitarcade has don't nothing for me so far because it relies on the callibration to be better than it is.

So as a product

a tool to keep skills sharp by using all the various options the software has to offer.

reviewText:
See my full review with screenshots and more at http://misstoxia.com/review-rocksmith-2014/

Rocksmith 2014 is both a game and learning tool for use with a real electric guitar or bass. You plug in your guitar to a USB port with a special cable and can play through step by step guitar lessons, learn specific songs and riffs and play a variety of arcade style games with your guitar as the controller.

Everything the game does is done in a very incremental, adaptive and intuitive way, from the games to the lessons, everything is designed to help you retain information about notes, chords and scales, etc, as well as building up your muscle memory to improve your skill at playing guitar. It’s obvious a lot of work and research has gone into making Rocksmith 2014 a powerful education tool that can teach anyone to play guitar while still being fun.

The lessons try to teach you how to play in the way a real guitar tutor would; by explaining techniques, showing you how they are played and then giving you a go while gradually making things more advanced each time. The practice riffs also slow down and let you do things at your own pace if it thinks you are having trouble.

There are also a decent amount of ‘Learn a Song’ songs that come with the game that start you off by getting you to play the very base notes that hold the song together, the game reacts to how well you are doing and gradually adds in more notes if you are getting everything right, eventually the notes will become chords and with enough practice you will easily learn how to play a song from start to finish.

The arcade games are designed to make you remember specific aspects of guitar playing as well as increasing your reaction time, muscle memory and being able to play without looking at the guitar neck. One game has you shooting ducks by playing the right note as they appear in front of different frets, another has you strumming entire chords in a zombie rail shooter. I found all the games to be both fun and very helpful.

Some other nice features Rocksmith 2014 has is a full tone designer where you can create your own digital sound using a variety of pedals, amps, loops and more. The real life equivalent of this kind of equipment is really expensive so I found it really fun to be able to play around with this kind of stuff. There’s also multiplayer modes, online leaderboards and session mode where you have an automatic band accompanying your guitar as you play.

I don’t have many bad things to say about Rocksmith 2014 other than the song selection not being entirely to my taste, but a few DLCs fixed that for me. I also had an incredibly hard time getting a Rocksmith RealTone cable in Australia, all of the retail stores were sold out for over a month and I had to order one online. Some may also argue that the game is too repetitive, but with learning any instrument, repetition is the key to success and I think this game really makes the repetition as fun as it can possibly be.

If you have a guitar sitting in the corner of your room which you don’t really play because you’ve given up on learning it on your own, then I highly suggest you try Rocksmith 2014, you will almost definitely improve at playing guitar, learn some new songs and have lots of fun. If you want to learn guitar on your own, this is the way to do it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pretty dissapointed with the song selection, but it's still a cool game.

Now what it REALLY needs is a mode that completely stops the song on every note and waits for you to play it before moving to the next, rather than flying them all past your screen. Because note by note is how we read and play tabs, right? You look down at the note, play it on the guitar, and move onto the next; it's not as if your eyes skim past the tab while your fingers helplessly play catch-up, but that's how this game does it.
Granted, you can emulate something close to that with their Riff Repeater mode set to 1% speed, but that also isn't perfect.
The note-by-note function is already present in the very start of the game, but you never see it again after that. I just wish the developers provided an option to play songs using that.

reviewText: Fight Club is one of the most unique films I have ever seen. In addition to presenting a rather fresh take on life, FC also presents its material in a fresh way. My main interest in the film is in that, in my opinion, it does not present characters for us to think about. Rather, it presents actions for us to think about. I will say that I cannot recall *ever* having been asked" by a film to both suspend my disbelief the way this film asks in its third act AND at the same time come to terms with an understanding that there is no room--or need--for disbelief.\n\nPerhaps these comments will not make sense to the average movie goer who will dismiss this film--and
recommended: its premise--as another hollywood flick filled with gratuitous violence. I'd go as far as to say that this film is not about violence. It is about choices. It is about activity. It is about lethargy. It is about waking up and realizing that at some point in the past we've gone to the toilet and thrown up our dreams without even realizing that society has stuck its fingers down our throat.\n\nI would argue that anyone caught
hoursPlayed: at some point in their lives
voteText: between a rock and a hard place--anyone who has reached bottom on a mental level--anyone who has uttered to themselves "Wait

voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A week ago, I didn't even know how to properly hold a guitar pick, and had no idea how to tune a guitar.  Since then, I've put about an hour or so a night into this.  Today, I went online, figured out I was able to read Tabs, and was able to play Saria's Song from scratch in about 30 minutes of practice.  I've still got a long way to go, but this is huge to me.

If you're wondering if this game can teach you how to play the guitar, the answer is a resounding YES.  You will get as much out of it as you put into it.

That said, the game isn't without its flaws.  It has a hard time reading certain notes, especially on my cheapo guitar, so you might have to play with the tuning to get it just right.  It also has a really hard time reading bends, making you feel like you almost have to snap the strings just to get it to read right.

If you've always wanted to learn how to play guitar, but thought it looked too hard or were too afraid to try, get yourself a cheap guitar, the cable, and this game, and you'll get over your fear really quickly.

reviewText:
I've been having a blast with this game. It takes the addictive elements of guitar hero and rock band, and teaches you real guitar techniques.

There are lots of fun songs across all genres to learn, and the game does a good job of letting you ramp up until you are playing every note. It also has a cool riff repeater" mode that lets you slow down and repeat sections of the song in order to practice. I've played about 50 hours of the game and I can actually play a few songs on my own already.

There is also has a mini game mode that turns practicing scales
date: chords and other drills into games
recommended: which is more fun than just practicing those things over and over.\n\nMy only complaint with this game is that it doesn't have very good tools for calibrating audio/visual input lag. I wish it had more robust tools like Rock Band does
hoursPlayed: because there's not much you can do to correct it. Overall
voteText: I'd recommend this to anyone who has had fun with Guitar Hero and wants to actually learn guitar."

reviewText:
Let's get down to business...
This game was certainly one of Ubisoft's best games. You require an Electric guitar/bass guitar and a Rocksmith Real Tone cable in order to play this game. But I'm very impressed with how it worked, I understand that there are so many glitches in this game, but when the game works, it is just amazing.
To simply state upsides and downsides, I'll list them:
Pro's:
You can learn guitar easily.
There are many songs to choose from whether it's Rocksmith 2012/2014, DLC, or CDLC.
You can get a Rocksmith 2012 import for Rocksmith 2014 giving Rocksmith 2014 a lot of Rocksmith 2012's songs.
There are lessons and arcade games to play which uses the Electric guitar, it certainly helps.
Missions to unlock songs/gear/inlays.
Layout is simple and easy, whether it's the interface or the Riff repeater.

Con's:
For some, guitar is hard to play, I certainly had trouble, and that was beacuse I didn't practice the practice tracks, which I recommend you do if you're having trouble shifting/bending etc...
DLC is way too expensive, asking £2.39 for a DLC with Rythym guitar, lead guitar, bass guitar and vocals... a little too much right? YOu can find all this stuff on the internet, but I buy these DLC's to help me learn the songs.
Some CDLC may crash, and a while back Rocksmith 2014 just kept crashing when I started a song or lesson.
Setting this up with a ♥♥♥♥. took me at least five hours to fix the bugs myself and get my guitar to be picked up on this game... thanks internet too.
Missions... now, these... are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I've never seen a game as bad as Rocksmith 2014's mission system... you had to do it... you had to be a bunch of idiots, put a basic coding into the missions, and from like... play 1 new song, you ask for 3. From a 10 note streak, you go up to 300 after a while, and you have to get 100% mastery in songs... and yet, no matter how many times I repeat the song, you can't get 100% mastery, and once it had bugged out and not registered. And every single mission is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, allow for skippable missions and I'd recommend wasting time completing missions. I have to alt-f4 and launch the game to get a decent easy mission since I am only a beginner. Ubisoft idiots went too far with judging players skills, Beginner mode is what I started out as, and because of missions, they appear to think I'm pro.

About the stupid coding stuff... let's just say, there's only 2 songs on each path that the game recognizes, or at least 3. 2 CDLC's and one Rocksmith 2014 song... why not any of the others? Why not? Seriously, fix this or at least release an expansion pack that doesn't cost anything.




But I recommend this game for the guitar player who wants to learn songs and learn guitar.
But this is not for completionists, it is impossible to complete this game, it's just an unlimited game.
For ♥♥♥♥s sake ubisoft, release updates for this, not DLC.

reviewText:
First off, I'd just like to say the big annoyance of this game. It is that every guitar and bass I own apparently has a really low volume. Every time the tuning screen comes up it says it. These are not low quality instruments. Apparently my massively loud Rickenbacker 4003 is too quiet! I don't not what guitars and basses they were testing with but seriously? So with that out the way I think I can talk about the rest of the game.

It's fun! Though I'd question it's worth as a teaching tool. I picked this game up with 7 years bass experience, so I haven't really used it as a teaching tool. I got it because I'm a big fan of guitar hero and thought it'd be cool if I could learn some songs on the way. Unfortunatly, many years of playing Guitar Hero have made me quite good a sight reading this game. Every time I learn a song in the game to 100% or near mastery, I can't remember a single note when I come away. This isn't so much of a problem with the game as a problem if you've played a lot of Guitar Hero that I thought you might want to be aware of.

This game has made me less prone to looking at the neck of my bass though. I didn't actually realise how much I did it until I started playing Rocksmith. It has taught me to only look down for the big jumps, which is cool. So it's not without it's uses if you're experienced.

The big thing I wanted to get out of this game apart from another cool rhythm game, is a few new songs to learn that I otherwise may not have thought to. It has done a great job of that. I've learned Radiohead, Stone Temple Pilots, Dead Weather. It's all good stuff. Plus there are an enormous amount of custom songs available for download. They're easy to install and they're all actually of pretty good quality that I've tried. Not like they were in Guitar Hero 3. So check this out if you want to learn some songs. Though I haven't seen anything that explains any music theory to you, which you really need if you're starting out. So maybe only get it if you already have a pretty good idea what you're doing.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game enough!  I've owned guitars for a long time, but never really stuck to practicing.  Most of the time before playing Rocksmith 2014, I would just fiddle around with making melodies and wanting to figure out how to make chords go along with the melodies I was creating.  I didn't get very far with Guitar.

When Rocksmith (original) came out I was excited to pick it up and give it a shot, but had many issues with the game:  Input Lag, Audio feedback, and just wasn't really into the method.
Then comes Rocksmith 2014!  So far I've put about 45 hours into 2014, and I'm still having a blast.  All of the issues I experienced on Win32/x360 versions of Rocksmith 1 have been resolved.  And now there is a recommendation system that suggests things for you to do.
Rather than level up like in the first game, you focus on mastery of each song.  Once you have mastered a section of the song, the notes will fade out, and force you to memorize the patterns. (brilliant! and optional if you dislike it)

I have yet to play Bass with this, but from what I can glean about being able to play Lead Guitar or Rythm Guitar, I expect it will be just as fun to play.  (I will probably pick up a bass soon; but there is a bass emulation mode as well for guitar)
I have a deep musical background, and the only thing I find lacking is that it's all focused on Rock.  (But it is Rocksmith after all!)  I wish it had some classical guitar tunes that can be very technically hard, so I could focus more on picking and more difficult techniques.  But overall this is a great start, and I'm excited to see where this takes me after another 40 hours of play (or practice)

reviewText:
This game (although more of an education tool than a game) takes the concept of gamification and successfully marries it with a hands-on guitar training program.

It's like having a personal guitar teacher chained in your closet, that you can whip out whenever you feel like, for as long as you feel like. It doesn't matter if you have never touched an axe in your entire life. He will sit you down, teach you how to hold the guitar, hold the pick and he will hold your hand through the first note down to the last. He will sit through with you, as you fumble your way through lessons that you are honestly not ready to start and no matter how clumsy or oafish you are, hitting the wrong string or fret time and a time again, he. Will. Never. Lose. Patience.

In one week I have learned more than I honestly believed I could ever learn with a guitar.

If you want to learn to play as well and you don't get this game, then you are stupid for it.

Get it!

reviewText:
I bought this after playing the original .  The main reason I wanted to upgrade was that the songs available for purchase in 2014 are much more to my taste (Billy Talent?!?!?  Awesome).  But it seems that this version runs a lot smoother on my CPU, has better visuals, and better latency than the original.  I absolutely recommend this to anyone who plays, or wants to play, guitar and bass.  A great teaching tool, and a lot of fun.

What I love about Rocksmith is it doesn't punish you for playing additional notes.  While playing rhythm parts you can feel free to jam out without worrying about losing your progression (or level) on the song.

I still think they need more songs... particularly acoustic/campfire songs.  A Donovan package would make me one happy camper.

More Iron Maiden, please!  Flogging Molly would be nice, too.

reviewText:
Read bottom of review for a condensed review
I bought Rocksmith when I had 5 days experience of playing guitar, so I was a complete beginner. To cut a long story short, 6 months down the line I can actually call myself a guitar player, but there are other factors which you may be interested in. Rocksmith is a great way to convert from playing guitar hero to a real set of strings, and the UI was one hell of a way to go about it. It's easy to understand and ushers you on your journey from pleb to rock god, so what about the game itself?

Well, if I am to be completely and utterly honest, all Rocksmith has done is teach me a few techniques, and how to play certain songs, sure it makes it more fun and attempts to immerse you in the song you're trying to master, but to be blunt, it is just music tablature, but with a more 'arcade' feel to it, and then of course there's a few minigames to try keep you from getting bored.

The cons? The song list seems particularly limited, which reduces the lifespan of the game. The only way around this is by 2 ways, 1) You purchase the DLC, which I personally believe is rather expensive, I'd prefer to see them go down to about £1.50 per track, but hey, you're learning an entire song right? So on that ground I'm not complaining too much. 2) Use custom DLC, which basically lets you import whatever song you wish into the game, provided the community has made the track for it. This is modding the game of course, and because it's ubisoft, it's probably against their terms, but it didn't stop me. Besides the song list, after using rocksmith for quite a while you begin to discover that all you are doing is learning songs, not so much guitar, so don't expect to be learning musical theory on this game.

Conclusion
Definitely not a subsitute for a real guitar teacher, but something that might assist a guitar student. If you just want to learn songs then this is for you, but don't disregard youtube or normal music tablature (which is mostly free). After 6 months, I find more use in the cable so I can use guitar rig instead of rocksmith.

6/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Initially this was alright, but the lag is really bad for playing. I can't stand it. Makes playing tricky fast sections really hard. Also its soo strict with actually playing chords. If you miss a note in a chord (or even play it a little too quiet) - it decides you havn't played it properly, even when it sounded perfectly fine (to my ears). Yet other times i would blatantly make a mistake which sounded terrible and it didn't catch it. It became hard to tell if i actually made a mistake, or the game was flagging false positives. I stopped playing after a while becuase of this.

Several months later i was bored one day and decided to checkout session mode and worked through a few more missions. Then i fully comprehended what you can do in session mode. Its the perfect practice tool, i started doing my scales and playing along with the band. Now I just jump in session mode and jam for a while, practicing new and old techniques. As there's no critical timing in session mode, the lag isn't so much of an issue. I am enjoying it way more now.

Overall i would recommend this game becuase of session mode. Once you had a bit of fun with score attack and learning a few songs, start using session mode and work through the missions.

Note: I would consider myself an intermediate guitar player at the time i bought RS2014

So, I started rocksmith a few months back noticing the youtube '50 days' videos and I had played some acoustic before but never really got the hang of it. So I purchased my guitar , a squier classic vibe (really solid, great sound for beginners) and purchased the cable and the game. Anyway, great game, I enjoy spending my time on a game and still learn :)

This game is excellent. I have been self-taught and playing guitar by tab for years. I could usually select any tab and make my way through it. reviewText:
I wish this game existed when I was first learning music. It completely lowers the barrier to entry for a starting musician. Years ago, you'd get your first instrument and make absolutely horrible noises for months, eventually graduating to semi-tonal, repetitive boring folk tunes. After about 5 years of hard work, you might actually be able to play something resembling a modern popular song. If you were practicing alone, you could only hope to simply play along to a recording if you wanted to hear the rest of the band.

Enter Rocksmith - now from the first note you play you sound awesome. The rest of the band is there, sounding awesome. Next time you play, you learn a little more. You still sound awesome. Do a couple of 5 minute lessons, learn how to sound more awesome. Not awesome enough? Put on some headphones.

There are enough songs to cycle through that your roomates/parents/neighbors aren't going psychotic after two weeks of happy little teapot" over and over and over again. Now

reviewText:
Is it a good game? -Definitely

Will it teach you how to play guitar/bass? -Yes

What did I like about the game?
-Riff repeater is great for practicing harder parts of songs
-The dynamic diffuculty scales nicely, though sometimes it will be completely unresponsive
-Minigames and session mode are fun, score attack shows just how much the rest of the internet is better than you and always will be
-Tone designer is fun to fiddle with
-Good but somewhat shallow selection of songs (not including DLC)
-They have something for every skill level

What didn't I like about the game?
-The note recognizing is pretty shotty at best, I play using a Epiphone SG and when I play the proper note it will either sometimes or very often give me a miss (It might be a hardware thing)
-ANYTHING TO DO WITH BENDS, the note recognition is attrocious for bends and you need to hit it darn near PERFECTLY for it to register. Very unforgiving
-The dynamic difficulty would sometimes become unresponsive and will stop raising or lowering the difficulty when you need it
-Master mode will hide the notes at the worst possible times
-Riff repeater would sometimes resume the song instead of repeating the specific section
-I never exited the game feeling satisfied, mostly frustrated or feeling like I didn't learn anything new or gotten better

Overall it's a good game and I recommend it wholeheartedly to beginners and amateurs a like, the little problems, while annoying, are rarely game-breaking. Play this on a good computer, this game demands a lot from it.

Number wise it's like a: 7-7.5/10

reviewText:
Read bottom of review for a condensed review
I bought Rocksmith when I had 5 days experience of playing guitar, so I was a complete beginner. To cut a long story short, 6 months down the line I can actually call myself a guitar player, but there are other factors which you may be interested in. Rocksmith is a great way to convert from playing guitar hero to a real set of strings, and the UI was one hell of a way to go about it. It's easy to understand and ushers you on your journey from pleb to rock god, so what about the game itself?

Well, if I am to be completely and utterly honest, all Rocksmith has done is teach me a few techniques, and how to play certain songs, sure it makes it more fun and attempts to immerse you in the song you're trying to master, but to be blunt, it is just music tablature, but with a more 'arcade' feel to it, and then of course there's a few minigames to try keep you from getting bored.

The cons? The song list seems particularly limited, which reduces the lifespan of the game. The only way around this is by 2 ways, 1) You purchase the DLC, which I personally believe is rather expensive, I'd prefer to see them go down to about £1.50 per track, but hey, you're learning an entire song right? So on that ground I'm not complaining too much. 2) Use custom DLC, which basically lets you import whatever song you wish into the game, provided the community has made the track for it. This is modding the game of course, and because it's ubisoft, it's probably against their terms, but it didn't stop me. Besides the song list, after using rocksmith for quite a while you begin to discover that all you are doing is learning songs, not so much guitar, so don't expect to be learning musical theory on this game.

Conclusion
Definitely not a subsitute for a real guitar teacher, but something that might assist a guitar student. If you just want to learn songs then this is for you, but don't disregard youtube or normal music tablature (which is mostly free). After 6 months, I find more use in the cable so I can use guitar rig instead of rocksmith.

6/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

The number and importance of the improvements they've made means you're losing out badly by not upgrading. voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
More than a game - can be classed as a teaching tool as well. Huge, HUGE improvement over the first Rocksmith game in just about every way possible. This is the best way for beginners to learn guitar with its many lessons while keeping it fun at the same time - also great for intermediate to advanced guitarists looking to improve or touch up on their skills.

The mini games are also a huge plus. They are basically lessons for scales, chords, slides and bends disguised as little arcade games. What other games make you say you played a beat 'em up with your guitar while learning scales at the same time? Exactly.

Session mode is a lot of fun as well. Pick your AI band's instruments, the complexity of the jam, a genre, hell, faff around with pretty much anything, and start shredding. The band plays along with you. You'll feel like a rockstar in no time! Fantastic way of learning how to improvise as well - especially when you feel confident enough to add mini solos for the hell of it. Great feeling!

That's not to say there's a couple of (minor) cons with this game. Sometimes the game crashes when picking a song or going to riff repeater, but it happens very rarely now. Also, the note detection, especially for power chords (for me, anyway) can be a little iffy. Also the in-game tuner is a little... whack. Get yourself a chromatic tuner, go with what the game says and then retune it yourself. Don't let this deter you from an absolutely amazing experience though. These are just the small problems I personally have with the game.

All in all... worth it. So worth it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Initially this was alright, but the lag is really bad for playing. I can't stand it. Makes playing tricky fast sections really hard. Also its soo strict with actually playing chords. If you miss a note in a chord (or even play it a little too quiet) - it decides you havn't played it properly, even when it sounded perfectly fine (to my ears). Yet other times i would blatantly make a mistake which sounded terrible and it didn't catch it. It became hard to tell if i actually made a mistake, or the game was flagging false positives. I stopped playing after a while becuase of this.

Several months later i was bored one day and decided to checkout session mode and worked through a few more missions. Then i fully comprehended what you can do in session mode. Its the perfect practice tool, i started doing my scales and playing along with the band. Now I just jump in session mode and jam for a while, practicing new and old techniques. As there's no critical timing in session mode, the lag isn't so much of an issue. I am enjoying it way more now.

Overall i would recommend this game becuase of session mode. Once you had a bit of fun with score attack and learning a few songs, start using session mode and work through the missions.

Note: I would consider myself an intermediate guitar player at the time i bought RS2014

reviewText: If you have an electric guitar, it will work. Works with my bass too. You can learn guitar totally, concentrate on lead or rythym or play a bass if you have one. It's also like a game guiding you. Alot like guitar hero but better and with a real guitar. I have it. I've been playing guitar since I was 6 on and off. Full-time since I was 27 and I'm now 43. I really like it. Fun. My fingers hurt or I'd be playing it right now. Can't have them bleeding since I also fly Phoenix 4 and Realflight 6.5 radio controlled flight simulators. (and the real thing there too..real trex 500 and blade 300x). Back to Rocksmith 2014 though...it works fine with my Fender bass and Fender guitar. Says it will work with every guitar. I haven't tried it with my 1967 Noble yet. Oh, I bought it with the cable retail for the same price as it is here. THIS GAME REQUIRES A CABLE. And I'd recommend buying TWO. I bought a second one since I have friends that play and we can play together in two player mode. So buy the game if you have a bass guitar or a regular guitar, but make sure they are electric guitars or basses and get two cables. Have fun! -Squiggy Wigginz owner of www.NakedCoed.Com

reviewText:

reviewText: I highly recommend this game if you just want something the jam to every once and while, tighten your guitar skills, or possibly learn how to play in general. I used to play guitar in a couple different bands about a decade or so ago, even traveled the west coast playing shows and opening for some decent acts... then I went to film school, left the music behind me (fun while at lasted, lead to a lot of firsts in my life :) but never managed to sell all my old gear. I've hung onto a couple of amps, guitars with various sentimental values and rarity in the market place through several moves, but in all honestly only jamed on them a handful of times, and usually just playing the old stuff form muscle memory. Rocksmith is perfect for me with a variety of progressive difficulties, and challenges to learn new material and get outside my comfort zone. Been working too hard to play recently, but since I bought the game I've plugged in more in the last couple of months then I have in the last several years! The Mavericks bug did suck though, dragging down my ability to use the software for several weeks, took them the better part of a month the fix... guess that's what I get for jumping into a new os that hasn't been properly tested.

reviewText: I was originally a bit skeptical but as the first game has been interesitng at the very least I decided to give this one a shot.\n\nI have to say, it puts the first game to shame. I had expected them to either focus on improving the game" part or simply make the game more of a digital guitar tutor; which was the primary issue with the first game as it failed to really properly do either. Instead
recommended: and brilliantly at that.\n\nAs a guitar tutor it eases you in if you are new (as it asks your skill level at the beginning) and is
hoursPlayed: unlike a human tutor
voteText: infinitely patient. As I had previous experience (including the first Rocksmith) I was able to jump right in. The lessons are much more fleshed out; with several of the techniques having several lessons and practice tracks to play to really learn the skill. Most importantly
helpfulPercent: the Learn a Song section of the game is not only accessable
votesHelpful: lets you choose what song you want to play and learn and do it. On top of this they made the Riff Repeater simply part of the Learn a Song
votesTotal: so if you want to go back and retry a part you missed you can do so. Slow it down
votesFunny: make it easier or max it out. You can do it at your pace and really learn what you want. You can even make it mark notes you missed so on th next pass you can be on the look out for them.\n\nOn the other side of the coin is the game mechanics. The first rocksmith tried to instill game mechanics through a kind of "path" but really all it did was restrain gameplay. Instead you have free access to every song and guitarcade game from the first moment you start the game. Not only this but they have added a "Score Attack" mode which approximates one of its plastic guitar forebears
commentsCount: but with the real thing. The guitarcade games have gotten a massive facelift as well. Most of the games in the guitarcade are not only solid but assist in developing key skills; and most of them are references to old school games (I was particularly impressed with the "Rad Racer" reference game Scale Racer.)\n\nOne thing I don't feel goes in game or tutor sides of the fence is the Session mode. Essentially it can be thought of as a virtual band that will jam with you. They don't follow any particular song
column16: and neither do you. You play what you want and they will join in as their AI decided to. You choose whatever instruments you want in your band
column17: how fast
column18: in what scale and go. The game teaches you how to play wiht the digital band (and even how to use this with a real band) and lets you have fun playing whatever you want.\n\nIt is really interesting in that you spend some time with an AI band and you can adjust your sound to match the band; or just rebuild the band
column19: or tweak it. Granted this doesn't allow you to write songs for the band to play; but instead it is what it says
column20: a jam session. You play what you want and the band does too
column21: they tend to be swayed based on what you are playing but you can even take more of a back role. Turn up the volume on one of the AI members and let them do their thing.\n\nAdmittedly there are some faults with the game. Firstly and most importantly
column22: a lot of the best and most popular songs are DLC. I understand that the base game is trying to pick and choose a wide selection
column23: but when you put the B or C lister songs from an artist in the game then put out A list songs as DLC it does feel a bit wrong. Granted you can knock this up to the song licensing company having higher costs for popular songs
column24: but it is irritating nontheless. Another thing is that occasonally the fact that the game doesn't catch a note due to the simply the game not catching a note will happen. Occasionally you will play somehting right and the game misses it. While I don't expect the technology to be 100% perfect
column25: it does get irritating
column26: and is especially common on palm muted notes.\n\nOverall for the price? This game is amazing. You get a guitar tutor that is infinitely patient
column27: willing to repeat lesson after lesson and tell you when you do things wrong. You get a long list of songs to learn
column28: even longer if you are willing to shell out a few bucks. You get a fully fledged rythym game where you can try to go for high scores. You get a slew of practice minigames that all focus on pumping up your techniques. You get an AI Band that will play along side you.\n\nAnd most importantly of all
column29: you get motivation that may not have been there before. One thing any musician will tell you is that you have to want to get better to get better; and Rocksmith 2014 provides so many reasons to practice just a bit longer that you would have to try hard *not* to get better at guitar from playing it."

reviewText:
I have written this on day 3 of my 60 day challenge.  The fingers on my left hurt and you can even see the marks now.  But, this is so much fun.

I am amazed that my terrible playing sounds like a member of the band of whatever song I am playing.

I am 50 years of age, and playing an electric guitar has always been on my bucket list.  Here it is, my best chance of crossing one thing off the list.  There are lots of challenges within the software, and it learns from you very quickly to the point of being too challenging.  Just stop things and wind down the speed or accuracy and away you go.

I bought a guitar, amp and stuff in a pack from an E-Bay retailer and then Rocksmith 2014.  So far so good, and the fun continues.

reviewText: I loved guitar hero back in its heyday, but found it too simplistic after going through a few games. That's when I decided to pick up the real guitar, but frankly it was a little difficult to commit in the long run because it was sometimes hard to find tabs, know what to play, and it didn't always sound great alone. It's been 3 years since I've touched my electric guitar so I decided that if I didn't get rocksmith, I'd never pick it up again. It was a great decision; for me the gameplay is about as much fun as GH but with practical experience, higher potential for difficulty, and it teaches very quickly. I can't wait to see how far it takes me. The biggest downside I foresee is the pricey $3 per song in the dlc, though the game has a good number of songs.

reviewText:
This game is excellent. I have been self-taught and playing guitar by tab for years. I could usually select any tab and make my way through it. This game finally introduced me to the theory side of music. **However, this game introduced me to theory by showing me new chords and new progressions/scales - I still had to take the time and learn a good chunk of the theory on the side. The difference... this game finally inspired me to do so!! I knew I had to understand these things to be a successful guitar player and Rocksmith ENCOURAGES you!!

The layout/interface of the game and the options it gives you are phenomenal. Sometimes I find it annoying playing one note every 5 seconds in Learn a Song" but Rocksmith quickly realizes you can handle it and adds more. Just wishing there was an option to get more notes/chords right away without having to use riff repeater to cheat the system.

Overall
date: this game is great for any level of guitar player (simply learning a song - beginner/intermediate
recommended: to playing session mode for hours trying new lead licks or creating new music - advanced). Hope this review helps you out!"

reviewText: With hardly any lag, a wide arrange of songs and my currently my main tool for learning songs on guitar, this game ranks as one of my few useful games. The songs are of different difficulty, so almost anyone can play this game. Having played guitar before always helps, anyways.\n\nAll the other music games I have played have not been about learning songs on an actual instrument, but rather pushing a couple of buttons to make sound. However, this game actually lets you learn the songs, as you use a real guitar. It will not force you to play the song as it is at once (Unless you choose it, that is), but it gets harder as you manage to play the songs better. This is a great tool for learning to play some songs, though it may not be for everybody. Everyone needs to find their own way of learning something, but this is probably the best way for me.

reviewText: Rocksmith 2014 is the best game/software I could possibly spend my money on. For a person who wants to learn how to play the guitar it is a great tool as well as entertainment. Apart from many improvements made in comparison to the first Rocksmith, you really have to appreciate the session mode. Learning scales, improvising, learning to listen to the virtual band, it is really helpful in improving guitar skills. I played guitar for quite a while, but having Rocksmith gave a huge boost to my playing ability. Even when it comes to things like learning songs it's much better than tablatures. I learn faster, it's more efficient, I highly recommend it to anyone. Beginners will find it easy to use, intermediate players will have a great tool for practicing in my opinion, and for those who like a challenge there are always difficult songs which are very demanding, and if that's not enough try everything on master mode (I actually like it a lot when parts or whole songs disappear while you play, after all the more demanding it gets the better you try to play). The thing I didn't like in the first Rocksmith as well as Rocksmith 2014 is the range of songs. Although the variety is great, I really wish there were a loooooot more DLCs to choose from and the prices could be a little lower. And now it's time to plug in the Real Tone cable again.

reviewText:
This game (although more of an education tool than a game) takes the concept of gamification and successfully marries it with a hands-on guitar training program.

It's like having a personal guitar teacher chained in your closet, that you can whip out whenever you feel like, for as long as you feel like. It doesn't matter if you have never touched an axe in your entire life. He will sit you down, teach you how to hold the guitar, hold the pick and he will hold your hand through the first note down to the last. He will sit through with you, as you fumble your way through lessons that you are honestly not ready to start and no matter how clumsy or oafish you are, hitting the wrong string or fret time and a time again, he. Will. Never. Lose. Patience.

In one week I have learned more than I honestly believed I could ever learn with a guitar.

If you want to learn to play as well and you don't get this game, then you are stupid for it.

Get it!

reviewText: I loved guitar hero back in its heyday, but found it too simplistic after going through a few games. That's when I decided to pick up the real guitar, but frankly it was a little difficult to commit in the long run because it was sometimes hard to find tabs, know what to play, and it didn't always sound great alone. It's been 3 years since I've touched my electric guitar so I decided that if I didn't get rocksmith, I'd never pick it up again. It was a great decision; for me the gameplay is about as much fun as GH but with practical experience, higher potential for difficulty, and it teaches very quickly. I can't wait to see how far it takes me. The biggest downside I foresee is the pricey $3 per song in the dlc, though the game has a good number of songs.

reviewText:
Rocksmith 2014 has helped me in certain aspects. I now feel like I can play a game with tabs instead of staring at a blank book/screen.

- No recording feature? I mean it would be fun to jam, and record with session mode.
- No free DLC sponsers?

All in all, a fantastic emersive experience that I cannot complain about.
Please make cables more bloody durable.

reviewText:
Guitar Hero but with a real guitar!
Rocksmith 2014 is an excellent piece of software that I really love. This easily goes on my favorite games list. It is the second installment of the Rocksmith series; the first game released in 2012. The new 2014 version has improved a lot from it's previous game.

I picked this up with 0% skills and barely touched a guitar before. By the time of writing this I have 140 hours on records and without a doubt improved a lot. I remember when I downloaded Take It Or Leave It" by The Strokes and tried to play I barely could keep up with the song and eventually miss a lot of notes
date: but now I can get above 90% accuracy in it.\n\nThere are countless of DLC for R14 mostly for about €2
recommended: 99. A must have is Cherub Rock by The Smashing Pumpkins because that allows you to download free custom DLC made by other people. Customsforge[customsforge.com] is the main website where you can get your favorite songs for free.\n\nAside from the game you need a guitar obviously and Ubisoft's Rocksmith Real Tone Cable which works with all consoles
hoursPlayed: both R14 and it's predecessor. It is basically a 1/4 jack plug[i.imgur.com] to USB. The cable was pretty hard for me to get because I don't live in the USA so the store I bought it from had to wait for a new batch to arrive which took approximately one month.\n\nHappy shredding!"
voteText: April 17, 2015

reviewText:
At first I was sceptical to this game, but that changed fairly quickly when I really started to put time in this game.

This game is extremely good for learning to play the guitar. You get about 30-40 songs with the game but fear not you can download extra songs and add it to Rocksmith. Google Customforge, make an account and download extra songs. (You cannot download official DLCs by Ubisoft from Customforge) In writing moment there are 17,070 songs up on Customforge.

What I think make this game so great is that you can slow down the speed of the song in Riff Repeater and on top of that choose a specific section of the song which autorepeats itself, this is an awesum feature. You can also choose difficulty but seriously who would not like to learn the song on 100%? I say - High difficulty - Slower speed - Learn the songs of your favorite artists! :D

reviewText:
I have been playing guitar a long time. Got this as a birthday present. I did not expect this game to be so huge.

Personally I think that it would not be wise to learn guitar through this as there are some pretty important differences in playing real guitar, like the immediate effects that get thrown on there, and the fact that the sound is an usb input which means information of the signal is lost, but the game on itself is really fun to do and gave me motivation to pick up the guitar more often. Also you skip the fact that you don't have to buy a lot of expensive gear to try to immitate the sound on a record.

An amazing surprise is how much effort the game put into the learning video's and especially the Session Mode". This mode forces you to learn the complete neck of the guitar and has definetly improved my solo guitar sessions. My muscle  memory and finger speed have both increased because of this mode.

Overall
date: I really enjoy the game and would definetly recommend it to guitar players who have been playing for a year or two and want to play along some great classics without too much effort."

reviewText:
Fun way to play with guitar! I've played guitar for years so I don't know how easy it is to learn with this, but still a lot of fun to learn new songs. At first it was a bit hard to read the note highway as I'm used to guitar tabs, but after a while you get it. And of course harder songs need to be learned first and not while playing for the first time the whole song.

Quality of the transcriptions will vary, some song are very good some are not as good transcriptions. Some lead tracks don't have rhythm almost at all which is in accurate in most cases. Mostly RS1 songs and DLC are crappier than RS2014, but had to buy the old one to get old dlc...

Otherwise I enjoy this, it's the best that is available at the moment, hope they bring new version later and add possibility to see the songs in TAB format! Only other I've played is Bandfuse, I like it more than this, but as the company is bankrupt, this is the best we can get.

reviewText:
As a bassists, I find Rocksmith 2014 to be an absolute blast to play. Before the only way I had to play these songs was by printing off tabs from websites, or by having to listen to parts of a song over and over again in order to figure out what was being played. The best part about this game is the Riff Repeater, which allows you to play sections of a song over and over at different speeds and difficulties. I was not a beginner when I started playing, but Rocksmith is a great way to keep my skill up.

The only cons with the game are the limited song selection starting out, and the fact that the song difficulty takes a really long time to change for advanced players.

Score: 9/10

reviewText: As for Rocksmith, so far it's done everything I've asked of it, short of giving me a real solid feel of direction. I'm probably going to regret not practicing the basic scales and chords as much, since I've been playing along with some hit songs more during my practice sessions. The fun factor for me is quite high, but I've only found annoyance with the GuitarCade mini games so far. The lessons aren't nearly as in depth and useful as I had hoped. It's also hard to gauge my progression in skill outside of each individual song. I've also noticed it may be a bit too forgiving for timing. I've been singing pseudo-professionally, and feel the timing window might leave too much leeway for folks who aren't particularly good at rhythm to begin with, not giving enough feedback to develop well. 5/5

reviewText: Since I used to love playing Guitar Hero, I thought it would be awesome to play a game like it while learning how to play the guitar. I like most of the variety of songs on Rocksmith and even if you don't like many, you always have the option to buy more. I believe that this game can be a lot of fun once you begin to get the hang of moving your finger up and down the fret board. After you play the game for a while you begin to realize that the game is a bit repetitive. I wouldn't recommend this being your only source of learning the guitar since it only teaches you the basics of playing the guitar. Though, I do love this game and I feel like I can play a little bit of the guitar now even though I haven't played it that much.

reviewText:
Before I bought this game, I was already a good guitar player. Not great, but I certainly knew how to play. At first, I struggle with the game because of the layout of the tabs. These are vertical instead of horizontal, but after a couple of plays I managed to memorize the colors of the strings. The lessons are very good. They are very clear on how they teach and they are totally optional.
The Soundtrack for the game is solid. I think there were some better songs that would have fit in the game instead of others. I wish there were more, but the dlc seems to take care of that. I wish the develepors wouldn't just have over $1000 worth of dlc and instead offer more songs at the start.
The customization of amps, effects, pedals, etc. is amazing. I have spent plenty of time just messing around with various effects trying to get one that sounds kickass! If you aren't looking for that deep of an experience, Rocksmith gives you the option to choose a songs effect instead of making your own from scratch.
The games are fun for a little bit, but I found myself going back to songs.

Overall: 9/10
The only problems I had with the game were problems with bends during songs as they would not count.
LESS DLC... MORE STARTING SONGS!

reviewText:
This is an amazing way to learn the guitar, it's taken me from not knowing how to properly hold a guitar to being able to play the basic chords, play parts of leads and hold down sections involving multiple strings.

Let me just list down stuff that other reviews might have missed, especially the ones that someone just starting out would want to know

1. No need to get an expensive electric guitar, i've been using a signature guitar (Rs 3500) and a humbucker type pickup (Rs. 650) to play this. It's not the best way but it'll still get you started

2. Constant updates: Team Rocksmith (RS) is continually rolling out improvements and new songs for this. At about Rs. 180 per song it might seem steep but compare that against taking proper guitar classes.

3. Broad range of stuff: Formal guitar classes mostly focused on getting me to learn a particular song. If you follow the RS missions they'll take you from songs, to learning scales, to learning techniques like bends (each of which has its own game that you can play while training your fingers) to various tuning styles of the guitar. It's more holistic than just being able to repeat a bunch of songs

4. Takes the boredom out of practicing: the point at which most people leave the guitar is the long hours spent training your fingers to move on the frets. It tedious, repetitive and there seems to be no improvement taking place. Rocksmith makes that fun by giving crazy arcade games, easy versions of songs, score challenges etc. You'll play it for the fun and sense of accomplishment while learning all the key skills

5. It's not a perfect solution: You'll still need to visit websites/youtube etc to get more info on the basics. It won't teach you to read tablature (tabs) that real guitarists use to learn songs. People will tell you to learn the basic chords first (A, E, D, B, C) but Rocksmith seems to favor power chords.

But it'll help you learn, it'll help you stick to the guitar when you would've grown bored and left it, and then one day you'll be a guitarist my son
