reviewText:
I have been playing guitar a long time. Got this as a birthday present. I did not expect this game to be so huge.

Personally I think that it would not be wise to learn guitar through this as there are some pretty important differences in playing real guitar, like the immediate effects that get thrown on there, and the fact that the sound is an usb input which means information of the signal is lost, but the game on itself is really fun to do and gave me motivation to pick up the guitar more often. Also you skip the fact that you don't have to buy a lot of expensive gear to try to immitate the sound on a record.

An amazing surprise is how much effort the game put into the learning video's and especially the Session Mode". This mode forces you to learn the complete neck of the guitar and has definetly improved my solo guitar sessions. My muscle  memory and finger speed have both increased because of this mode.

Overall
date: I really enjoy the game and would definetly recommend it to guitar players who have been playing for a year or two and want to play along some great classics without too much effort."

reviewText:
Great way to learn guitar!  I already knew how to play rhythm guitar pretty well just by learning from tablatures over the years, but I was never good at scales or soloing.  This game has increased my dexterity quite a lot and CDLC is an awesome way to learn songs that aren't already official DLC or aren't likely to become official DLC (I listen to a lot of indie music).

If you ever played Guitar Hero, it's definitely much harder but it's also that much more rewarding because you are actually learning to play the song for real.

If you have always wanted to learn guitar and just could never motivate yourself to actually learn, buy this game!  It is THE best tool for learning and is adjustable to EVERY skill level, even someone like me who knows their way around a guitar but still is lacking in certain areas.

reviewText: Plug in your guitar, learn to play songs. Rocksmith is pretty straightforward on the face of it. But underneath the hood are the tools that players of all levels can use to improve their performance, from Guitarcade mini-games, which make speed and technique drills better and more rewarding; to the Riff Repeater, which can slow down a single section of a song so that you can get it down right. A vast amount of DLC for this game means you should be able to build a huge library of songs you enjoy playing, and the Session Band lets you put together a band that will automatically play along with you.\n\nIt should be noted that a Rocksmith RealTone cable is required to play this game, and that costs extra, so if you want to save some money then you should buy Rocksmith on sale. But any guitarist who feels like guitar games are a good idea but that implementing that with a toy instrument is disingenuous should look no farther than Rocksmith 2014.

reviewText: Rocksmith 2014 is amazing. I began playing guitar at 12, and when I was 13, I got the original Rocksmith for my Xbox 360. I played the heck out of it, and it helped me learn many techniques I would have otherwise never known about. I have since progressed with my ability to play guitar, and bought Rocksmith 2014 on my PC. I was very grateful that my RealTone Cable from my Xbox 360 was compatible with my PC. I started the game up, and shreded away. The best part about the Rocksmith franchise is that it is not biased towards beginers or experts. You can start the game knowing nothing about how to play guitar/bass, but if you give the game some time, it will pay off, I promise. The best feeling while playing this game is when you reach 100%+ mastery on a song. I remember the first time I did. I noticed the notes seemed to be fading away until they did not show up anymore. It was as if I was jamming to this song in my room. The game automatically put the song on Master Mode" seeing as I had already been hitting every note. I finished the song
date: and I was ecstatic to see that I had 104% mastery. This game is for anyone interested in learning guitar
recommended: or simply just jamming if you already know how to play. Do be warned though
hoursPlayed: it's like being on a diet; results do not show up overnight. If you want improvement
voteText: give the game time and patience
helpfulPercent: and be sure to practice frequently."

reviewText:
More than a game this is a tool that makes guitar learning fun. This edition offers a simpler and better interface, with a much more streamlined experienced when compared to the original Rocksmith. You no longer have to go through 10 menus to play a song and back through the loop to play it again. Career and free play modes have been condensed into learn a song, which brings you right to track list which you can sort in a number of ways including difficulty or recommended, which replaces the old career stages, meaning you no longer have to go through that particular song you don't like and don't want to play in order to progress.

Experienced players should enjoy the option to set the difficulty right to master mode from the start and use the game as colourful moving tabs, also the new session mode which lets you form and ajust your own band to play along your jam sessions. The continuous play mode is neat as well, you can set the time and remove songs you don't want to play and just go along with what gets thrown at you.

For begginers you get a nice set of lessons and practice minigames that help grasp or refresh the basic techniques. These aren't compreehensive and don't replace more thorough resources but serve well in providing you with the fundamentals to jump on to the stage and massacre a classic or modern rock song you know and (used to) love. It's a blast when you hit that 1 note that nearly made the song sound alright, much better than painfully repeating tedious lessons with no sense of progression.

The track list is considerable, including DLC and the option to import all the content from the original Rocksmith, you are going to be doing a lot of scrolling. So far I haven't found any major flaws with this edition, however there are some mildly annoying details (grab your seat!), the new achivements are crap, you will get 10 for visiting the uplay store (whatever that is) and none for reaching master mode in a song for the first time, which brings me to my major complaint thus far: half the time you will try to log in with your uplay account and you will get a server is not available try again later"
date: which is harmless until you want to play that new song you just bought and can't because you need to be connected to uplay and activate it in the ingame store after buying it on steam (thanks jewbisoft). Curiously the first Rocksmith had none of this uplay mischief
recommended: and so the DLC you get from the original gets imported automatically without the need for uplay consent.\n\n9/10 - I look forward to hundreds of hours of relentless cacophony. By the time I hit half the notes in Aces High I'll probably be a chosen champion of Slaanesh and have sprung into existance a noteworthy cult
hoursPlayed: mostly consisting of unwilling neighbours whose mind and spirit will eventually bend with the force of my unstoppable musical onslaught. But I will have one hell of a fun ride along the way."

reviewText:
9.4/10 - This is VAST improvement over Rocksmith 1. A complete overhaul.

The greatest feature of Rocksmith 2014 is one thats not even included. The modding community. In a heartbeat, you can download hundreds and hundreds of custom songs. That alone is worth the $60.

YOU CAN SET DIFFICULTY TO ANYTHING AT ANY TIME. The worst part of Rocksmith 1 was lack of difficulty control. Rocksmith 2014 so effortlessly integrates riff repeater, that in learn a song mode (most peoples favorite mode), you can start and exit a song 5x faster than Rocksmith 1, and riff repeater is available anytime before or DURING the song. My favorite mode, in the guitarcade, score attack, lets you choose between Easy, Medium, or Hard, with Hard being all phrases at 100%. Not sure what set percentage it is for Easy and Medium, but its constant. And i like this mode because it keeps track of scores more effectively and uniformly.

Session mode: You pick you backing track, drums, basses, guitars, pianos, percussion, you pick you scale and your key, it shows you a fret board with every note of that scale. And highlights the ones to land on according to the current chord playing. This is just mindblowingly helpful for people just started out in the improv and jamming department, such as myself.

As a metal fan, I'm liking the song and DLC selection quite a bit more in this game than the first Rocksmith, though again, with the customs, that doesn't matter too much. Anyways...

If you bought Rocksmith 1 and thought it didn't live up to its potential, GET ROCKSMITH 2014. It fixes all of Rocksmith 1's caveats. Ubisoft really hit a homerun on this game. I've already recommended this to 3 friends who went out and bought it because they're trying to learn guitar. The only reason you should not have this game is if you have absolutely no interest in guitar.

reviewText:
Some people who are familiar with me might remember me talking on launch day about my excitement at finally getting to learn guitar and my plans to post all kinds of updates as I got better and stuff. Those same people might realise that I never did that. (Good old college finals wrecking everything...) So now that I'm finally on break, I decided to start putting some serious time into Rocksmith 2014 starting with the new year, and make learning a thing or two about guitar my new year's resolution, so to speak. Well I've managed to keep with that promise to myself fairly well, and have been playing quite a bit this year, making sure to spend time practicing and doing finger workouts (Yes! Finger workouts!) every sing day. From my time spent right after buying Rocksmith 2014, I'd learned a few things about playing, but hadn't put much serious work in till the start of this year, so in effect the 4 days of 2014 I've had prior to this post are the only real time I've spent actually trying to learn and improve and not just screw around.

(TL;DR I've been practicing for 4 days)

Now that we've got that little bit of exposition out of the way...

Wow.

Rocksmith works. It seriously works. It brings all the tools to the table for you to use, and then just simply shows and helps you use them to improve, and improve fast. After 4 days of Rocksmith and a few youtube videos, I'm comfortable enough with the fretboard to play through a handful of the lower difficulty songs with solid hit rates, able to figure out spots I'm having trouble with and practice them until I feel comfortable, and challenge myself to get better all while having fun and actually feeling like I'm making progress.

In fact, the feeling of making progress is my favorite part of this game/tool. Every single time I stand up to play it, I feel like I'm moving forward, becoming just a little bit quicker with my fingers, more consistent with my strumming, and more accurate with my timing. This software manages to perfectly blend combine a learning environment with the entertainment and approachabiality of a game in a way that's convinced me that I want to learn, I want to keep hammering away at Blitzkrieg Bop and Next Girl, that I want to struggle with the weird way Smoke on the Water is played, and that I want to spend time learning guitar rather than playing other games.

(TL;DR After 4 days I feel like I've made real progress, and I'm motivated to keep progressing)

The game won't teach you guitar yourself, you've got to bring your own motivation to the game to get anything out of it, but if you're willing to work, the game helps you in ways that make your work feel rewarding. I finally brought my motivation into Rocksmith, and I'm starting to get skills out of it that I find absolutely amazing, and I can't wait to see how much more progress I can make the next time I stand up and play.

(TL;DR If you're motivated, like I am now, this game will help you turn your motivation into real guitar playing skills.)

Absolutely reccomended.

Edit: Just as an FYI, I bought this with the Epiphone Les Paul Junior through Amazon for $200, and I'm extremely happy with guitar as well.

reviewText:
When I first heard about the Guitar Hero franchise, I thought it would be a game that you actually play with a guitar.  I ended up enjoying a few of the games, but I was always dissapointed by that cheap plastic controller that it came with.  A few years ago Rocksmith came out and I finally had the game I had always wanted.

The first Rocksmith game was an awesome teaching tool.  I was pretty much an absolute beginner when I got it.  Today I've still got a long way to go, but I'm miles ahead of where I started, and I can now complete some of the easier songs with 100% completion.

Rocksmith 2014 improves on the base game in almost every way.  Menus are easier to navigate, the rift repeater tool has been overhauled, and support for more tunings.

reviewText: A solid upgrade over the previous version. Definetly great for begginer players like myself. It helped me build my hand dexterity and endurance in addition to being great fun. It's really great to be learning an instrument (in my case bass guitar) while actually playing music with it. If you are more of a technical person this does offer rather good technique guides and exercises. One thing that is a bit dissapointing for me personally is the session mode. I cannot claim this to be true for regular guitar but for bass it just feels unnatural and sounds like some out of sync backing tracks. Sometimes it does sound good enough and I can't really fault them for trying but I mostly used it to practise scales. Also had a small issue at launch with the instrument playback being way too silent. However the issue has been adressed and is solvable by a simple windows options tweak.\n\nOverall a great learning tool (as I don't really feel like calling this a game per se) and lots of fun. Vastly superior to the original Rocksmith which I got few months before release of the 2014 version in order to get the cable and now I have basically doubled the songs available for me. By suplementing the game (which provides a great practise environment) with musical theory and technique guides available online (shoutout to http://www.scottsbasslessons.com/ for some superb free bass guitar content) I feel like I'm really developing my playing skills faster than I otherwise would have just with theory alone. Give it a shot!

reviewText:
Firstly, before I turned on the original Rocksmith for 360, I was a complete noob at guitar. Now I can pick up any guitar and play and sing along with a pretty impressive song list. By the time you read this review you'll see I've spent nearly or over 500 hours on this game. It's my most played game in my library, averaging around 10 hours a week, sometimes more if I get a wind of motivation going up to as much as 20 hours a week. Point is, I clearly like this game, and you don't need a review to see I would recommend it. You can do that just by looking at my profile activity. Note: My Steam time isn't my total time spent on guitar. I dabbled with the original Rocksmith, played quite a bit of 2014 on the Xbox 360 before switching to steam and have also spent roughly the same time playing acoustic.

But this isn't just a game. It's a game that teaches you a real skill, so instead of answering the usual questions of how the game works (It's got a UI similar to the Guitar Hero and Rockband games) or the graphics (Pretty straight forward here. Graphics are functional but not over intrusive over the note highway). Instead I'll answer the question people are really interested in ’If I buy this game, will I learn guitar?’.

I can’t answer that with a straight yes or no. However, if you were to say to me, ‘I’m learning guitar, should I buy Rocksmith?’ the answer is a clean yes. Why? Because Rocksmith is NOT the ultimate tool for learning guitar. It can, however, be used as part of a toolbox of educational tools (all free minus price of guitar) to strengthen many of the skills needed for effective guitar playing. It just doesn’t teach you them all. If you buy it expecting it to magically teach you guitar in a few months, you’ll be sorely disappointed. If however, you’re committed to learning the guitar, you’ll find it an irreplaceable tool. There are certain things that unfortunately Rocksmith can’t teach, and it comes down to the will and determination of the individual to plough through these physical limitations.

For example, if you’re a complete novice picking up your first guitar, you have two hurdles from your body. Firstly, you’re lack of knowledge of the fretboard will have you spending more time staring at your hands position then anything else. This can be frustrating in Rocksmith because trying to play a song, even on the easiest difficulty, will still result in more time looking at the fretboard than the screen. This causes frustration and that’s dangerous because that is when people will start to think ‘Screw this, I’m going to go play to play League of Legends’ or whatever the young people are wasting their time on nowadays and the guitar is never picked up again. Another common issue for the novice is limb independence. This is a person's ability to move one arm independent of the other. At the early days of learning a guitar, again, you’re going to want to focus on hand position and the fret board. This means being able to strum without thinking about it and that’s a challenge in itself.

Trying to master both at the same time can be rough for a guitar noobie, and it’s the first and most common wall people will give up on. The good news is that everyone has the same problem when starting out and it’s simply an issue of muscle memory, meaning if you practice then the body will learn by itself and if you stick at it, you’ll have one magical day when something clicks and you’re body just starts to work. You won’t have to think about strumming and your hands will feel like they are more naturally falling into the chord shapes at the right position on the fretboard. This is a magical day for all budding guitarists, and this is when I recommend moving on to Rocksmith because now you’ll be able to play the simpler songs on 100% difficulty at full speed and once you do that, you’ll start to actually feel like a guitarist.

Rocksmith’s gift is that it is second to none for being a tool develop accuracy and muscle memory in many of the skills required to play guitar. Add CDLC (Google it) and it becomes essential. If you’re already learning guitar you can jump in at any level and take advantage of Rocksmith. It makes practice time, fun and easy to measure progress. However if you want this to magically and effortlessly turn you into an irresistible guitar playing woman magnet.. well, keep dreaming.

SIDE NOTE AND RECOMMENDATION
If you genuinely want to learn guitar, then instead of starting here, I recommend buying an acoustic and putting ‘easy acoustic song tutorial’ in to Youtube. Start with something like Green Day’s Good Riddance or Oasis’ Wonderwall. Learn the basic chords and get efficient at transitioning between these chords and strumming at the same time. This may take months, even a year of solid practice, maybe even longer. There will be times when you feel like you won’t get it, but I promise your body will eventually start to move on its own. Then move on Rocksmith. Stick to the Rhythm side of things when starting out and once you’re able to strum and change chords effortlessly, move on to the more demanding Lead position with songs that have the face-melting solos. The trick is gradual and persistent practice. Trust me :)

reviewText: I only" have  about 11h of playtime on this program when writing this review. date: Jimi Hendrix or KISS in the 70s and never wanted me to be a guitar stomping maniac \m/(~.~)\m/\n\nAnyways
recommended:
I picked up a guitar a few years ago but never really got me more than strumming a few chords. My problem certainly was playing not daily as I used to on my other instrument.
Note: It's not just about talent or a teacher- even the best teacher can't practice for you! You need to play and practice regularly with a certain amount of devotion and variety.

And this is exactly what this "game" does. You pick a song you'd like to learn und play guitar hero like by first just plucking a few notes; the program recognizes your failures or your skills and advances the next time and/or recommends to practice the riffs you've been bad at.
I can't tell how much fun it is to learn a song step by step.  It's highly motivating. I never played the guitar as much as now. If you're really into really into learning guitar... then get Rocksmith 2014 and the cable! You'll never regret.

ROCK ON!"

reviewText:
Seeing as I have 200+ hours on this game and only 13 achievements you probably think I've been idling and probably haven't played all of the game. The second part of that sentence is true as I have spent the majority of those 200 hours playing songs that have been modded in by the extensive, constantly growing community.
When people think of modding normally they may think of reinstallling skyrim countless times due to corrupt files and installing loads of pointless software off dodgy websites. Rocksmith isn't like this. All you have to do is 1. own a DLC off the game (they cost a pound it isn't bad) 2. download a song of your choice off about 700 pages of songs 3. Change the DLCs ID so the game thinks it's the DLC you own. Thats briefly what you need to do theres tutorials all over the internet on what to do. I've installed 360 different songs onto this game and I've never had an issue.
When I bought this game I wasn't a noob to the games. I had played the original game which was alright and I had been playing guitar for years anyway. I've used this game to practice songs for performing and it has been very successful. The design of the game is simple to use and easy to play along to. This game is one of the few good ubisoft games (other great titles being king kong the video game and Howrse.)

In summary this game is perf if you want to learn or become better at guitar. Once you've played the base game theres a hell of a lot of CDLC for you to chose from.

Only bad thing is you have to pay for Smoke on the water" and thats just down right offensive."

reviewText:
This game is absoluetely wonderful, even for intermediate players to advanced.
I play bass and this is not only an amazing way to learn songs but a phenominal way to achieve the bass tone you've been trying to, without having to buy expensive pedals. The custimization is surreal, Im able to listen to my self play on thousands of dollars worth of equitment, while only having a 500 dollar bass. Its wonderful because one day when I do decide to buy the expensive amps and pedals ill be very well prepared on what sound im wanting to achieve to help me with my future purchases. Tone Desiginer is worth the 17 bucks I spent on this game. And CDLC is fantastic for importing songs that Rocksmith otherwise cant get.

Even if you dont have the real tone cable, you buy this program when its on sale, and purchase the cable later, its worth every penny.

reviewText:
YOU CANNOT USE USB HEADPHONES OR SOUNDCARD WITH THIS.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
That being out of the way (I fought it for a while, trying to figure out why it wouldn't work.) It's a pretty neat product.

The dynamic difficulty level works really well, but I didn't expect it to throw single string notes per beat for someone who chose 'average' as their skill level. I've played guitar for slightly over 10 years now, and those simplified tracks got me off guard, making me miss notes on songs I've played for years. It did pick up on my performance quite fast, though, and I started having a blast learning songs I probably wouldn't have picked up otherwise.

Make sure you set your skill level high enough.

Instrument used: Schecter Diamond series Omen 7 Extreme

reviewText: This game, after about a total of 150 hours with both games, has taught me to play guitar better than any teacher could. When I first got the original game, I had never picked up a guitar before and had only played Rock Band and Guitar Hero. By the end of the night (after about four hours of playing), I had managed to master Song 2 by Blur. After that, I was basically sold that Rocksmith was the greatest thing ever, but the 2014 version is miles better than the original.\n\nWay more lessons, session mode, more techniques, etc. than the original game. This has to be the best purchase I have made in a very long time and I recommend it to absolutely anyone wanting to pick up a guitar and be able to play it after some minimal practice.

reviewText:
Much better than the original, this is a must have for anyone interested in guitar.

I've been playing guitar on and off for over 25 years, since buying my first guitar in high school. For various reasons, I never took formal lessons on guitar; although, I have taken formal lessons on quite a few other instruments (clarinet, saxophone, piano, chello, violin).

I've successfully taught myself how to play many songs in fingerstyle guitar on acoustics, but could never progress very well with electrics. So, I could never really crank out the rock tunes that I grew up loving.

When the original Rocksmith came out, I immediately purchased it and played for a week or two, but couldn't get used to the notation, and stopped playing for months. Then, when Rocksmith was released on PC, I thought I'd give it another chance. At the same time, I was starting to play rhythm guitar in a band (badly), so any method that might help me learn was welcome.

I decided to give the original Rocksmith more patience, and after a few weeks, was noticing that I could play things with a pick, on my electrics that I had never been able to play before. I was also building up the ability to play chords and progressions that I'd never pulled off successfully.

However, the original Rocksmith had a long list of flaws that made the experience often frustrating: poor note detection, stability issues, performance problems, long loading times between menus, interesting, but poorly implemented games" for guitarcade; the list goes on.

Rocksmith 2014 has fixed all of those issues. Assuming your machine meets the minimum requirements
recommended: Rocksmith 2014 is a pleasure. With improved notation capabilities
hoursPlayed: in the last 3 months
voteText: my bends have gotten significantly more accurate
helpfulPercent:
I can palm mute and frethand mute in ways that I've never done before.

Are there still some issues? Yes. Is Rocksmith 2014 worth it? Absolutely.

However
votesHelpful: Rocksmith 2014 will not teach you everything you need to know. Youtube videos or some commercial online guitar teaching sites can augment Rocksmith very well. And
votesTotal: of course
votesFunny: a live guitar instructor will be able to provide feedback that will help you advance all that much faster."

reviewText: Rocksmith 2014 improves on the original in significant ways.  It's obvious the developers really care about Rocksmith and getting people into the joy of playing music.  I'm playing on a midrange laptop with headphones and the experience is smooth as silk.  The teaching aspects are encouraging and never leave you feeling overwhelmed.  The mini games are really fun and challenging such that you're getting more skills practice without really being aware of it.  The setlist included is diverse enough to cover most tastes and the additional songs coming out will help keep everything fresh for the long run.  Several people have complained about the tuner, but I didn't really have any trouble with it.  I'm sure there will be patches that wil fine tune the package over time.  Overall, I'm extremely impressed.  You can't beat the feeling you get when it all comes together and you're nailing it.  If you want to get started playing a guitar or bass, or you enjoyed the first Rocksmith, you need to pick this up.

reviewText: This version is a massive improvement to the first game. It loads faster, the menus are much easier (and snappier) to navigate.  The actual game itself feels snappier as well.  I do very much like their decision to move away from the Guitar Hero style career mode, and focused on it's strengths as a tool for guitarists veteran or novice to learn, practice, and play music they like. I also feel that the base set of music is much more diverse and relevant than in the first game, and I'm looking forward to buying more songs for this game.\n\nOnly gripes about it are the initial price, especially if they are going to be selling song packs, but I'm sure that the price will go down in the coming year.  That being said, I would highly recommend picking it up, especially if you want to learn to play guitar.  Picking up a cheap $100-300 guitar and this game will definitely save you a lot of money in the long run, because it does not require any other gear, and by time you feel comfortable playing the guitar, you'll have saved enough to buy an actual rig. But ultimately, any guitar will do. Right now I'm playing with my sister's guitar that came in one of those $90 starter kits from Best Buy, and it works perfectly. Can't wait to go home and try it with my own guitar.

reviewText: Rocksmith 2014... Well, I played the first one and before anything I must say, this one is a real improvement! There are some things missing though... There's a very annoying latency issue that can make professional guitarrists or anyone that plays on a real amp for sometime really mad! The Session Mode is the star of this new version, I bought the game just for it and as far as it seems I'm really enjoying it! There are lots of stuff you can do with it. The game itself is pretty much the same, there were a lot of graphic and sound upgrades, and the new Online Teacher is a quite nice feature. The new setlist presented in Rocksmith 2014 is full of wonderfull content, as well as it's DLCs. The Riff repeater feature is better than ever, allowing you to stop in the middle of a song and repeat that phrase, controlling the difficulty and speed it will come at you. I miss the old revenue and guitar picks of the old version though... But this one won't fail you! Indeed, Rocksmith can help the Guitar Noobs become real Guitar Heroes!

reviewText:
I've only dinked around with a few guitars over the years. I ultimately have very little idea what I'm actually doing with the guitar (save a few chords and memorized riffs here and there). Pure noob.

When I first heard about the concept of Rocksmith years ago I was very interested in the idea of a Guitar Hero or Rock Band type game that you actually played a real guitar. (I was a huge fan of those games.) The problem...I didn't know how to actually play a real guitar. Could it be possible that a game like Rocksmith could teach me to really play? The verdict went out, most reviews and videos I watched came back ecstatic about Rocksmith being not only a game, but a fantasic teaching tool as well. The only downsides I caught wind of were a horribly designed interface, some sound interface and gain issues. Alas I decided to hold off and moved on never purchasing the 'original Rocksmith' game.

Then came Rocksmith 2014. The same excitement bubbled up within me about a life long desire to teach myself guitar and play some of my favorite rock songs I've been listening to over the years. But would the game have fixed it minor short comings from the prior release? The reviews came in ....fantastic, 10/10, 5 stars, 9.5/10 etc.etc. Wow. They got it right and what's more they seemed to have greatly improved not only the interface, but the whole game experience itself. From the in game arcade where you can hone your guitar techniques that many guitar instructors teach in their lessons. To a great lesson section in which all the techniques and terminologies are carefully and skillfully delivered to those who need them, along with a practice session that increases the difficulty as you perform the lesson better. Then (of coarse) the actual learning of a song. Wow. Super fun. The problem with the real guitar lessons that my friends and other took is that they plateaued and grew bored with their slow progress and lame nursery songs for beginners. Rocksmith masterfully throws that old paradigm out the window and allows the player to learn their favorite songs, but at the level it detects the user can handle. Then it slowly increases the skill level as you master more perfectly the notes/chords that are launched your way. It is fun, motivational, and very progressive. Your skill will increase in just the first few weeks alone.

The game also includes and virtual band called Session Mode where you can play with your own band that you define and calibrate then play with. They adjust to your key/chord progession, tempo, style...etc.  Just another of many wows within the game. This game is a gem and has found it's place in my heart.

Ubisoft it seems has fully embraced the notion that a game like Rocksmith is equally used as a learning tool to learn from scratch how to play the electric/rythem/bass guitars, or the hone your skills even if your a guitar shredding vet. Both types seem to be happy with what Ubisoft has delivered this run.

Their are of coarse a good selection of tracks included with the game itself. Or they are always adding to the growing library of DLC songs or song packs to more greatly expand your library of favorite guitar songs/licks/riffs etc.

I haven't played a game where I was actually learning something that truly had a place and meaning outside of the gaming world. What a breathe of fresh air. They are trailblazing a new type of genre in effect. Not just the guitar playing genre, but the learning a real skill game genre. (lame name, but you get it.  :P  )

Very excited about this one. It's just different in all the right ways from anything else out there. Try it, find out for yourself.

-GooseSwan

reviewText: Rocksmith 2014 neatly combines Game aspects along with Teaching aspects. Viewed as a game, it's solid--there are achievements, a very smooth difficulty curve with the game adjusting to your abilities on the fly, feedback, and a proper sense of progress.  Viewed as a guitar (and bass) tutor, it's excellent. The UI is well done, with intuitive controls.  There is no noticeable lag, and the hardware (a usb to 1/4inch jack dongle) is solid.  My guitar is a junk fender strat clone, but works well with the game.\nThere is a large amount of DLC too. Pity it's never on sale!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Having a guitar sitting around for a year or so now, I decided to pick this game up to actually learn it. I was surprised at how much I actually learned just in the first day. In fact, you learn almost everything you need to know about guitar in Rocksmith that you need in order to play. The problem arises in the ways in which you are able to practice. As I suspected, the game is riddled with connectivity issues between the game and the guitar you are using between the Real Tone cable. Being a former 'professional' Guitar Hero player myself, I was afraid that the mini-games would be pretty much unplayable, and I was right. Sometimes strumming the correct note will result in a miss, and if strummed hard enough, you can actually strum any note, and the game will classify it as the correct note. Overall, I would still highly recommend picking up Rocksmith if you want to learn guitar. But I would advise staying away from it if you want to use it to practice.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Having never picked up a guitar before, this was a bit of a difficult one for me to justify.  However, having messed with it for coming up on 20 hours at the moment, I can say that it's well worth it.  The lessons are simple (though you may hve to grab some outside material for everything to click), and the games are exceptionally fun, if occasionally frustrating.  I'm not 13 anymore, so I don't expect to get anywhere near good as quick as the young'uns will, but this game is able to keep guitar fun and interesting, a tall order for an instrument with such a steep learning curve.

As for the DLC, I'm pretty sure the older Rocksmith stuff is compatible with the newer, and once you see how much work goes into every single song offered (the riff breakdowns, the practice modes, etc.), the price is understandable.  If I can eventually get to Satriani level, ultimate success for all!

Also, don't forget to get the tone cable.  Game won't work otherwise.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game enough as a learning tool for beginners wanting to jump into playing guitar and/or bass for real - this is no Guitar Hero, but will also gently guide you both within songs, across songs and different technique lessons to a more confident level of playing.

And for you shredders, the game adjust automatically to your skill level even within the first play, adding to the feel of real challenge. The Score Attack and Guitarcade are also highly entertaining ways of spicing it up with variety too. The only thing that sucks is the DLC price, but finish enough missions and challenges and you'll consistently earn new songs anyway :)

11/10 wouldbang.

reviewText:
The Ubisoft guys did a nice job on this version.  I previously had the Xbox version, and I hated playing on my console through a TV.  The HDMI lag was not great.  With Rocksmith 2014, I bought the Steam version, installed in on the Mac i use for music work, and have it running through my studio setup.  Makes all the difference in the world.  Zero lag, great sound.

Improvements this version include a session mode, where you pick a key and some band members, and they just sort of follow along with you.  While they arent the best backing band, it does give you an opportunity to practice scales and riffs with a rythm section behind you.  Another improvement is that it seems to more accurately catch what you are playing, shift difficulty at more appropriate times and the riff repeater is superb for really learning a part.  You get a ton of control over when it ups the difficulty (or whether it does) and speed.

I've been playing guitar, rythm, lead and bass, for over 30 years now, and I can honestly say that while I thought this was going to be a toy, ala rockband, I have definitely increased my skill by playing it.  At first I dismissed the guitarcade as a gimmick, but it definitely has made my scales faster, and my accuracy and fretboard position awareness significantly better.

The only complaints I have are:

1. I wish riff repeater was slightly more controllable as to when it starts and stop instead of being such large sections.  There have been a couple times where I was trying to learn a tough little flourish that occurs at the end of an easy section, and had to play the easy section over and over to get to the short riff because i couldnt shorten the RR selection enough.  That said, I got really good at it :)

2. The instructions for getting the Rocksmith 1 content should have been clearer.  I did finally get it to work, but I shouldn't have had to go to the forums for answers, that should have been a simple step by step process with rock solid documentation.

Overall I give it a 9/10.  Great tool for learning, and even for those of us with lots of experience there is a lot of learning to do.  It still amazes me when you spend 10 minutes on it, and suddenly pick up a tricky section as they throw it at you seemingly out of the blue at times.

reviewText:
I need to start by saying that this is not my first time playing a musical instrument by any means.  However it is my first real attempt at learning to play guitar.  After 2 weeks of using Rocksmith 2014 I can say that I've seen a major improvement!

Rocksmith 2014 starts you out easy, playing maybe 1 out of 10 notes through easy passages, and maybe 1 out of 20 through the more challenging parts.  As you improve Rocksmith throws more at you, and if its too much at first it backs it down a notch.  After each time playing through a song the program will show you your longest streak and your accuracy, along with song mastery and a few exercises that Rocksmith 2014 believes will help you improve the next time.

Pros:
1) Simple, effective and user friendly set up (note highway, similar to Guitar Hero)

2) The riff repeater is very helpful allowing you to repeat a section over and over until you get it, and will let you increase or decrease difficulty (awesome for learning solos)

3) 50+ songs ranging in style

Con:

The in game tuner is off, and its finnicky.  On day two I broke my high e string because the in game tuner insisted I was flat and told me to tighten the string until it broke.

All in all Rocksmith 2014 is an excellent practice tool, and you will get what you put into it.  Like all other musical instruments the key to proficiency is consistent practice.  It will not make you a rock god over night, but if you practice you will build skill.

helpfulPercent: without having to go into a separate area. When you're done with it

votesTotal: which gives you some direction if you're looking to improve. The game basically figures out which things you're good at at which you suck at
votesFunny: and recommends tracks that utilize those techniques to make you better.\n\nThe game looks better visually and the frets are labelled as well as the fingers
commentsCount: making it easier to use. Purely visual
column16: but when you practice now

reviewText:
I chose to begin and learn electric guitar on Rocksmith 2014 and it's been ~10 days since i bough the game and I can already say it's veeeeery helpful.
You can learn musics you like, there are good tutorials, and the arcade mode is very useful and fun. In ~10 days i progressed a lot with this game, so if you want to learn guitar and you can't have a teacher to help you learn guitar, just buy this game ^^

reviewText:
Rocksmith really delivers on its promise. I have tried learning to play the guitar before and though it started sounding nice enough to make out what I was playing at some point, invariable I'd quit within a month or two. After my guitar had been gathering dust for a couple of years a friend of mine recommended Rocksmith and I decided to invest in learning this skill one final time. This time around I've been playing much longer than ever before, trying to put in an hour each day if I find the time. I can actually play along with some classics pretty nicely now, something I was never able to do before to this degree, not to mention I'm now mostly able to play without watching the frets all the time.

Pros:
Does a very decent job at recognizing what you play.
You can set it up to automatically increase the difficulty and/or speed.
Small mini games teach you essential skills and help you practice them in a much less boring way than if you would practice them normally.
The Guitar Hero-like interface helps making the learning experience feel more like a game.
Cons:
The songs in RS2014 are somewhat harder than the ones in the first Rocksmith. You'd need to splurge some more to get those songs by first buying the original software and then spending some more on the import tool required to get those songs into RS2014.
Some of the DLC that you haven't bought yet clutters up your song list, obviously urging you to buy it.
The guitar tuner is a bit wacky. Sometimes the precision tuner tells you the string is tuned correctly, but the double-check it does afterwards will not pass. Getting past this point is difficult and skipping the tuning process because of it doesn't help either because the same string will give you trouble during the song causing you to miss" notes.
2 dollars per song (DLC) is quite a lot of money if you want to build a nice library.
Despite my list of cons being longer than my list of pros I'm still very happy with what Rocksmith has done for me and I will definitely continue to use it to hone my new skills."

reviewText: There isn't much to actually say about this game. It's basically Rock Band (or Guitar Hero) with an ACTUAL guitar! Your six strings are color coded so you can easily find the string to strum (for example, the red string is the thickest string on the guitar, yellow is next, blue after that and so on). Next is the fretboard in the game, it shows numbers on the interface (3, 5, 7, 9, 12 and the other dot places). It also comes with an in game tuner for many different setups (unlike the original 2). Also something I chose this game over the original was the official songs (songs that come with the game, not DLC), it has AWESOME tracks, not just stuff by bands that got famous by these games (with a few exceptions), it's got Bat Country by Avenged Sevenfold, Say It Ain't So by Weezer (side note, I've spent the most time here because it's good practice for chords), My Own Summer by Deftones and many more!\n\nThere is one BIG downside to this game though, the way the game's programmed, you need a pretty good guitar with brand new strings, and not too many pickups and stuff. I don't know why but, sometimes the game reads your tuning as right in the tuner then says you're tuning is completely off during a song. Here's a good example, you tune your guitar as close to the 0 mark as you can get (in this one, that's near impossible to do), then you strum the right note at the right time, and it says you either didn't hit it or you hit it late. All because of the way it's programmed. If you don't have a $5,000 guitar, I recommend you get the original Rocksmith as it isn't as picky with your tuning...
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The most important thing to mention with the original Rocksmith & the 2014 edition is that they motivate you to play, which is the hardest barrier to overcome when learning or improving in guitar. I can fully recommend both for that reason alone with 2014 easily being the superior version.

Having spent close to 200 hours with the original Rocksmith I wasn't hesitant in pre-ordering the 2014 edition for almost the songs alone. While the original had some flaws, 2014 addresses all the major ones, improves the game in every way & adds some great new modes. I've seen some complaints on having to pay around $10 to import the songs from the original Rocksmith (the dlc from the first transfers for free), but I think it's understandable due to the licencing fees. Also it came as a welcome surprise that all the original songs have been redone, benefiting from the improved techniques such as improved bends, and have become more accurate to the original arrangement.

If you've ever wanted to learn guitar or bass or need the motivation to improve I'd suggest Rocksmith 2014 as an additional aid as well as being great fun once you've become comfortable with them.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Decent learning tool. Defintly for novice guitarists like myself to lean the ropes.  However it is not perfect.

The note detection is hit and miss.
How the tracks are set up, slowly adds notes once you hit a track perfectly or removes them when you miss a fraction, is a decent idea. Once you put it into practice though it is psychologically frustrating.

Here is why. Once you learn a riff on a lower dificulty you have to relearn that riff again when the difficulty ramps up. Subconsciously you are relearning a single song multiple times over and over again. Then muscle memory will not have a clear memory to focus on. Leading to frustration for guitarists. No matter who I talk to about Rocksmith is irritated with the software.

You can however max out the song and play at slower speeds then manually make them faster over time. This slightly less irritating because hitting/missing unkown chords or riffs will continue regardless. What would make it better is for the a training mode to stop a track until you hit the note or the chord perfectly then move to the next one to get a taste of the dish. Then move on to nonstop tracks.

Occasionaly, on my rig anyway, the chord is very picky about how it is placed in the guitars output. Buzzing sounds cut off all outputs as well as the output cutting off alltogether.

Rocksmith provides a lot of information and is a decent escape for bordem.
But you could search for the same information online for free.

reviewText: While the game itself is a wonderful learning tool and fantastically fun for beginners and experienced guitarists, I cannot recommend the pc version of this game due to the windows drivers issues that many people including myself have.\n\nThe USB cord for the guitar should a simple process of plugging it in to a USB port and once the drivers are downloaded, they will be saved and remembered the next time you plug and play. Instead the drivers are reinstalled everytime you reinsert the USB cable. Sometimes the driver downloads as it's suppose to as Rocksmith USB device" but more often than not it downloads "USB Audio Device" which will not work
date: or even worse just "hocksmit" which does not work. I purchased a ton of the DLC songs hoping to add some songs I can learn to only find that the game has become unplayable after hours of trying to reconnect the device to get the correct usb driver.\n\nPLEASE create a driver which we can downloaded instead of the automatic driver detection ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I relize that it is probably Windows at fault on this issue but if that's the case
recommended: cut them out and provide an easy solution to all those who have purchase your game for PC."

reviewText: Not a game, but a tool. An AMAZING tool, but don't go in expecting this to be a game experience. If you've never played a guitar, your fingers will hurt. You will also learn to play things. If you do already play guitar and want something to motivate you to practise more or just learn some new songs in a fun way, it's great fun. The Guitarcade games are a really well-disguised drill program that actually makes you better at techniques in a fun way, and there are little tutorials for all kinds of things that you my have never tried before even if you are experienced. This game solved the problem I'd always had with tremolos (I was holding the pick wrong. Simple fix, but the tutorial videos showed me what's up) and taught me some new techs too. If you have an interest in guitar, enough that you've already bought the instrument but have no idea where to go next, this is a no brainer.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText: About an hour in and I can see that this is a vast improvement over Rocksmith, which I poured over on 360 and then dabbled on PC.  The menus are snappy, and you can infinitely practice a song section however you like.    One of the reasons why I dropped off the first game was that it did a pour job of teaching you the chords for a song.  You couldn't practice chords easily, and as someone who knows nothing about playing the guitar, I was just completely lost and a bit frustrated.  It felt like I hit a ceiling and there didn't seem to be a way to improve.\n\nIn Rocksmith 2014, the adaptive teaching system in the game gives you a set of tasks for each song to help you incrementally learn how to play it in real life.  It tells you what sections you want to practice, what chords you should learn, and just feels more like a teaching tool and less like a game.  The greatest improvement is that the riff-repeater is much like Rockband's riff-repeater, just infinitely looping a section and letting you adjust speed and difficulty on the fly.  No more loading, no more do it five times to beat your score" gimmicks
date: just the ability to practice how you want
hoursPlayed: there are still goals and objectives
voteText: and the carrot on the stick is the various unlocks that the game will dole out to you as you meet these objectives
helpfulPercent: but if you're just here to learn how to play guitar (or more importantly
votesHelpful: have fun playing some classic rocks songs)
votesTotal: then Rocksmith 2014 is made for you.  I know I'm definitely looking forward to learning some of my favourite songs in the game.\n\nAs an aside
votesFunny: the cable itself should be easy to find
commentsCount: especially if you can find a bargain bin copy of Rocksmith for one of the consoles.  I'd also recommend waiting for a sale on the first game and purchasing the disc import tool to give you instant access to 50 or so more songs to play - considering the price of the DLC
column16: that's a very cheap way to bulk up your song library."

reviewText:
This is the perfect companion for learning to play! You learn the fundamentals the fun way, (something that can't be said about many instructional alternatives). And as for learning the songs, this Rocksmith surpasses the former by making sure you learn and recall sections by heart before you haphazardly continue, they even ocassionaly remove note annotations when they are certain you can play without further instruction (aka Master Mode).
The menu can be tricky at times and one might find that editing particular functions can take a little bit longer and can be a tad confusing, but that shouldn't be an issue for most users.

All in all, I highly recommend this to anyone, whether the person is already familiar with their instrument or simply starting out.

reviewText: This is a great tool for learning how to play guitar. I had the first Rocksmith when it came out and I wasn't too impressed with it.The style of unlocking songs a la guitar hero made some stints of the game really boring, where I had to learn songs I didn't care about to get to the good stuff. Plus, untill the Bass DLC dropped (while I was unable to even remotely dream of playing the game) you could only play lead/rhythm guitar. So when 2014 rolled out of the garage with it's shiny new wheels, I decided to give it another test run. Needless to say I'm thrilled with the changes they've made and there's a wide variety of included artists, and more are being added at a surprisingly quick rate. So with the technique lessons and guitarcade helping me learn the skills, and then score attack helping me see my progress actually progress, I'm loving every minute. I'm playing Bass right now, but I might bend and pick up an Electric Guitar to give rhythm and lead a try. That's how fun this game is, as well as how good it is at teaching. I WANT TO LEARN EVERYTHING!
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a great idea, performed only adeqately, with very limited diversity in song choices. They had the chance to make this game completely top notch but they settled for much less IMO and are really grubbing of the money about it too. I'm very disappointed that you cannot purchase all of the DLC at the advertised prices. Only the DLC specific to Rocksmith 2014. Otherwise you have to purchase the original Rocksmith ($29.99 right now on Steam and Amazon) and then another $10 tool to import the songs into Rocksmith 2014. Then you have to pay for the $3.00 song that you wanted in the first place. They are just sticking it in and twisting it, coming and going.

They should have had some finger-picking and classical rock songs included but nothing like that. No rockabilly or hot rod sounding rock (like Commander Cody, Junior Brown, Johnny Cash). No real good blues rock either (Gary Moore, Seasick Steve and the like). I mean what artist wouldn't want millions of people learning their songs the correct way? How hard is it to sign up these artists? Well those are the main bad points about the game IMO.

The good? Well it does a pretty good job of recognizing my guitar's notes for the most part although I have to repeat notes sometimes in the arcade games. Many of the songs are also very good and seem to be complete including multiple (dual) leads. There are tons of great sounds and effects for the guitar and lots made up specifically for the featured songs. You can slow the song without changing pitch with the riff repeater, allowing you to really zone in on tough licks. I also really like Session mode which really made me think a lot more about chord tones. There should have been some lessons for recognizing and utilizing them more effectively.

I like the game. It's really more of a practice tool and its pretty effective as that. I have recommended it to friends and other musicians I know. Its just that I believe they could have done the game better and they probably will in the future ( I hope anyways)

reviewText: This game is simply amazing.  If you are looking for a quick way to learn the guitar, or if you are already skilled but want something to test you, or just want to make practice fun this game is for you.  The detailed system really gives you that one on one feeling of going to lessons, and the learn a song mode breakes down into segments and lets you learn it at your own pace by starting off slow and getting more difficult as you do better in the song, or if you are feeling really confident you can ramp the difficulty up to max from the very begging.  Also you can now use your computer as an amplafier and add any type of effect to make all kinds of different sounds.  As if all of these awsome features were not enough they have added the all new session mode making it easy to just jam out with a band that changes with you and pushes you to solo.  This game is a great buy for anyone with a guitar with any amount of skill.

reviewText:
This is the perfect companion for learning to play! You learn the fundamentals the fun way, (something that can't be said about many instructional alternatives). And as for learning the songs, this Rocksmith surpasses the former by making sure you learn and recall sections by heart before you haphazardly continue, they even ocassionaly remove note annotations when they are certain you can play without further instruction (aka Master Mode).
The menu can be tricky at times and one might find that editing particular functions can take a little bit longer and can be a tad confusing, but that shouldn't be an issue for most users.

All in all, I highly recommend this to anyone, whether the person is already familiar with their instrument or simply starting out.

reviewText: About an hour in and I can see that this is a vast improvement over Rocksmith, which I poured over on 360 and then dabbled on PC.  The menus are snappy, and you can infinitely practice a song section however you like.    One of the reasons why I dropped off the first game was that it did a pour job of teaching you the chords for a song.  You couldn't practice chords easily, and as someone who knows nothing about playing the guitar, I was just completely lost and a bit frustrated.  It felt like I hit a ceiling and there didn't seem to be a way to improve.\n\nIn Rocksmith 2014, the adaptive teaching system in the game gives you a set of tasks for each song to help you incrementally learn how to play it in real life.  It tells you what sections you want to practice, what chords you should learn, and just feels more like a teaching tool and less like a game.  The greatest improvement is that the riff-repeater is much like Rockband's riff-repeater, just infinitely looping a section and letting you adjust speed and difficulty on the fly.  No more loading, no more do it five times to beat your score" gimmicks

The Guitarcade.

reviewText:
YOU HAVE TO GET THIS
its an awesome game that takes songs, techniques and lessons to any level you choose making it as easy or as hard as you choose. learning songs is the best part of it, because of the riff repeater. If you're struggling with a solo or a verse or even the whole song it lowers the difficulty for you or you can choose how much you want the difficulty to be. The other reason that learning songs on Rocksmith is the fact that it feels like you are playing in a band with all the music while you play. The percentage at the end just makes you want to get to 100%.
Yes it does have some flaws like it doesnt always pick up notes unless the volume is at max (might just be my guitar) and the difficulty can go from easy to quite difficult on certain songs, but you can't do anything about that.
But overall I love this game and have learnt more in a month of playing this than i  have over the past 3 months of youtube and guitar tabs. A MUST BUY FOR ANY GUITARIST!!

reviewText:
Rocksmith 2014 makes for mostly good times jamming on the guitar (there are some frustrating moments found due to a few poorly executed features and what seems to me a lack of several obvious features that should be included in the game). Many good ideas are implemented as practice games (in the style of classic arcade) to develop coordination and technique. While it is a much better game than the previous Rocksmith, it still leaves a lot to be desired in order to become an excellent practice helper and song tutor. Rocksmith 2014, while generally good, is currently just a good, not great, game for jamming on guitar and most likely improving one's guitar playing. However, it could become a great game with further development.

Rocksmith 2014 is good, but hopefully there are better things to come in a future release such as having the game automatically adjusting your E standard tuned guitar to sound like it's in alternate tunings rather than having to manually tune your guitar for dropped or open or raised tunings in songs, being able to play technique games in alternate tunings rather than just E standard, menu navigation by playing certain notes such as little or big E strings to navigate up and down, an option that allows us to listen to the songs like a jukebox without playing along on guitar would be much appreciated, and I could go on and on with more suggestions!). With all of the talented people that worked on or consulted for this game it's a shame that there is so much more that could be done that is simply lacking from Rocksmith 2014. Could the plan perhaps be to hold out on features thus ensuring the purchase of a future installment? I would love to have a better iteration of this game, but please provide more features that seem obvious as much-needed inclusions!

Rocksmith 2014 won't replace what you get in lessons from a great teacher. With the need for improvements and further development notwithstanding, this game is still worth picking up as it is the best thing available when it comes to a game that you can play with your own real guitar and most likely improving your guitar playing. It's mostly a good time (aside from frustrations encountered due to poorly thought-out features that need to be improved) especially considering that it will only set you back the cost of a couple lessons.

reviewText:
ok, so I have been using this game to teach myself how to play both bass and guitar. It does work, and quite well, however there are a few issues:

1) There's really no incentive to practice chords outside of a song, nor does it do a good job of teaching said chords. True, there is a chord book that you can use, but I have found it to be of minimal use.

2) The cost of song expansion packs is a little steep. But you will get bored with the standard song set rather quickly, so you'll need to buy more songs.

3) As far as I can tell, there's no online play, like there was with Rockband or Guitar Hero. Totally different games, I know, but still.

Overall, these few issues are miniscule to the positive aspects of the game. The learning curve can get a bit steep, but its not bad. Overall, I have found this more useful in teaching bass rather than guitar, but that might be due to my fat fingers, who knows. If you wanna learn how to play and don't wanna take a community class or hire a teacher, this is a great way to go.

reviewText:
This game is a big improvement on the original and fixes nearly all of the really annoying problems it had. I highly recommend this if you are into guitar or bass at all, beginner or advanced.

The good:
* Session mode is a huge addition that lets you improvise over a customizable band that reacts to what you are playing. This alone is worth the purchase price.
* The tracklist and DLC so far is great and if you own Rocksmith you can import the 50 songs from that for $10
* Large video library with lessons working from the very basics to more advanced techniques
* Master mode will now gradually fade out notes from sections you do well in rather than throwing the entire song at you with no notes.
* Riff repeater makes it easy to stop in the middle of a song and practice a section at any diffulty or speed you want. This is a HUGE improvement.
* The new score attack with leaderboards is a lot of fun once you have a song down pretty well
* The interface is, for the most part, much better.

The bad:
* The game seems much more forgiving on single notes now but can be very difficult to get chords to register completely throughout an entire song. Bends work fine on guitar but the game seems to have trouble recognizing them consistently on bass.
* While the guitarcade games are better than the original's, they suffer from a lack of options and too much downtime after a loss to really be a great tool.
* Still no way to just just study the tabs without playing the song
* Career mode is gone and the game no longer plays back your performance after you've finished.

reviewText: This is easily my GOTY. I've been playing guitar on and off for over 15 years, and I could have only dreamed to have this when I first started out. Part of the on/off nature of my playing through the years is just getting bored - picking up the guitar, noodling around with the same old riffs, looking up some tabs here and there, but otherwise doing the same old thing each time. With Rocksmith, there's so much to do and with the riff repeater it's so easy to practice those trouble spots that I normally would have just skipped over before. It's got a great song selection and even though I may not necessarily like the style of some of the songs, I still enjoy playing them as they each bring something new and different to the table.

reviewText: Potentially a lot of fun, but for an experiencecd guitarist the non-standard notation feels bogus and simply frustrating. When you need to grind and learn a song that you could easily play prima vista on standard guitar tab, it takes away most of the fun, of which there definitely there would be a lot of. Other gripes include latency issues, though less bad as in the first game and some note detection troubles especially on lower chords.\n\nBeginners shouldn't be bothered as much by the tab problem (although why not just have the normal tab as option, as it is a beneficial thing to learn in itself?) and the session room can be fun for all levels. So recommended, but not for everyone.

reviewText: It is a great improvement on the previous iteration, faster load times, more intuitive e fluid tabs, session mode its a great and fun way to pratice scales e harmonies, and the little arcade games offer a good fun way to pratice a few aspects of guitar playing. Unlike the previous Rocksmith which had a game mode, this one does not, so its more of a learning tool than a game. It's a great way for beginners to learn guitar, if you are a intermediate or advance player not so much, altough you can still have lots of fun with it. I would love to see added a feature to allow you to control individual instrument tracks in 'Learn a Song' mode, or at least the ability to solo the guitar tracks, also the ability to control the master level of the song while playing because sometimes it is a little boring having to play the same song a few times in the lower easier levels in order to get to a level that will challenge you.

reviewText:
This game is a big improvement on the original and fixes nearly all of the really annoying problems it had. I highly recommend this if you are into guitar or bass at all, beginner or advanced.

The good:
* Session mode is a huge addition that lets you improvise over a customizable band that reacts to what you are playing. This alone is worth the purchase price.
* The tracklist and DLC so far is great and if you own Rocksmith you can import the 50 songs from that for $10
* Large video library with lessons working from the very basics to more advanced techniques
* Master mode will now gradually fade out notes from sections you do well in rather than throwing the entire song at you with no notes.
* Riff repeater makes it easy to stop in the middle of a song and practice a section at any diffulty or speed you want. This is a HUGE improvement.
* The new score attack with leaderboards is a lot of fun once you have a song down pretty well
* The interface is, for the most part, much better.

The bad:
* The game seems much more forgiving on single notes now but can be very difficult to get chords to register completely throughout an entire song. Bends work fine on guitar but the game seems to have trouble recognizing them consistently on bass.
* While the guitarcade games are better than the original's, they suffer from a lack of options and too much downtime after a loss to really be a great tool.
* Still no way to just just study the tabs without playing the song
* Career mode is gone and the game no longer plays back your performance after you've finished.

reviewText:
Ok so I really liked the original Rocksmith. I liked the way there was a story element where you'd arrange a set list, and then you had to practice those songs until you'd mastered them to then rock them in a performance. You'd get points and streaks, and it was all very competative.

Well there's none of that anymore with RockSmith 2014, and I think that's sad. The catalog of DLC songs is now vast, covering classical through to spoof acts. Playing and practicing the songs is fin, don't get me wrong... but it just doesn't feel like a game anymore. There are arcade challenges, but it's really not the same thing.

All this said, I still can't put the gaem down. I've clocked up more hours playing this than I have romping though the entire Borderlands trilogy (1,2 and Pre-sequel) combined. It's definitly improved my playing ability and technique, but if you're already half proficient, some of the tutorials do feel like you're being taught to suck and egg.

If you're completely new to guitar... don't get this game. Buy a book or get a friend to show you the basics. If you've already been playing a month or so, this is proably not a bad investment. If you've been playing for more than 5 years, this is going to be too easy. In you're in that sweetspot in the middle, pick it up.

Oh, and I thought session mode was going to be awesome... it was a bit of a let down IMHO.

reviewText:
After playing this on consoles I picked it up on Steam for one reason.

The Guitarcade.

RS'14, as much as it wants you to believe it, is not a teacher, is not a replacement for a teacher, and will never be a teacher, while it's Lessons can be informative to the freshest of beginners the examples given in the lessons (placement of notes, what strings to play said note) can be very damaging to someone forming new habits".

What it is to me is a practice tool
date: if you have the basics of holding your guitar
hoursPlayed: or even a few chords
voteText: then Rocksmith 2014 is a great tool to help refine and poilish those a bit more
helpfulPercent:
in an environment you are %100 comfortable in (IE; your own home!).

Want to get the hang of shifting along the board? Fire up the Duck shooting minigame for 10-20 minutes a day.
Want to speed up your Tremolo? Jump into the Hurdles event!
Want to polish up your chords a little? Storm the castle and kill zombies
votesHelpful:
or fly through space blasting ships into oblivion!
Bends? Temple of Bends will get you practicing your half-step and whole-step bends on a way you can see!
Wanna run some Scales? Scale Racer has you covered there as you weave through traffic in an addictive way to remember scale patterns!

It's not all rosey however!

While this software can be a very
votesTotal: very useful tool
votesFunny: it gives no insight into "Music".\n\nThere is absolutely no theory to learn from here
commentsCount: if you want to know what makes a chord
column16:
a chord... Rocksmith isn't gonna help you there.

Want to learn notation? there's none to be had here which I think is this softwares biggest crime.

This is for someone who owns/has owned a Guitar for a while

column18: for the absolute beginner there are some pretty big pitfalls and chances to develop bad/hurtful habits if using RS and RS alone as a teaching aid.\n\nMy biggest gripe is it's community

not Guitarists who play Games.

reviewText:
YOU HAVE TO GET THIS
its an awesome game that takes songs, techniques and lessons to any level you choose making it as easy or as hard as you choose. learning songs is the best part of it, because of the riff repeater. If you're struggling with a solo or a verse or even the whole song it lowers the difficulty for you or you can choose how much you want the difficulty to be. The other reason that learning songs on Rocksmith is the fact that it feels like you are playing in a band with all the music while you play. The percentage at the end just makes you want to get to 100%.
Yes it does have some flaws like it doesnt always pick up notes unless the volume is at max (might just be my guitar) and the difficulty can go from easy to quite difficult on certain songs, but you can't do anything about that.
But overall I love this game and have learnt more in a month of playing this than i  have over the past 3 months of youtube and guitar tabs. A MUST BUY FOR ANY GUITARIST!!

reviewText: This is a a really fun game, and a really useful learning tool using real instruments. The genre has come a long way since the days of plastic Wii guitars, and despite a few hiccups in the interface, I think Rocksmith 2014 is the best thing in its class to date.\n\nThe 2014 edition represents a large improvement over the first iteration, and I can only recommend it to guitarists and bassists of any level. Of course, Rocksmith alone won't make you a graet guitarist, it's only another tool in the belt and it can never replace you going out and jamming with other folks. That's all I have to say for now. 9/10

reviewText: As a guitar player of quite a few years I got this mostly to just have some tracks to jam to along with a scoring system to make practicing more fun.  Even with a super fast pc, there is still lag, enough to throw a real guitarist off.  But by far the worst thing about this game is the horrid tab system it uses.  NO guitarist uses tab like this whether you reverse it or not it's still crap and too 'guitar hero'y.  If they woudl have just used standard tablature with a bouncing ball or highlighter it would have been infinitely better and easier to use.  The way it scrolls is a pain as well as it's hard to see what's coming.  Would be much easier to have a couple lines of music on screen at a time. I get the need to make it look like a game but that design choice makes it a poor music application and teaches bad habits as a guitar player.

reviewText:
The game is pretty cool and well made, but if you already have experience on playing guitar and you just want to improve then I dont think this is a good way. You can learn songs with the game but its harder, I've spent a lot of money (the game doesnt come with a lot of music, so you have to buy as dlcs and it is kinda expensive, also you have to buy a cable which is not cheap either) and time and I dont see a big improvement, getting tabs on internet or in a book its a lot easier, I find confusing the way they tried to fit everything on the screen and you have no idea what the tablature looks like so the notes keep coming and you dont know what to do.
Although, if you like guitar hero ( like me) its really fun to play but takes time to get used to it.

For me its a 5/10

reviewText: Not a very good learning tool In my opinion. Ive played for a few years and this just made me get stuck, just go to songsterr and learn songs that way much easier and youll remember them better. You'll also need to buy the cord seperately if you don't already have it. Now I remember why I gave up on learning guitar for awhile when my only tool was the original rocksmith on ps3. Dont waste your money.

reviewText: It's pretty frustrating that there's no option to display the music as sheet music or tabs. It feels like more effort is being put into learning how to read music a la guitar hero than being put into learning the songs themselves, and for what? Sure, if you're a complete beginner and like how easy it is to get into then maybe, but otherwise just buy a book and learn.

reviewText: Rocksmith 2014 is everything that Rocksmith was, but better in every way. If you want to learn guitar or bass, regardless of your prior experience, RS2014 will teach you! Buy this game. Buy it! BUY IT!
